<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The term "Bible" can refer to the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> or the Christian Bible, which contains both the <a href="/wiki/Old_Testament" title="Old Testament">Old</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testaments</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>The English word <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Bible" title="wikt:Bible">Bible</a></i> is derived from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Koin%C4%93_Greek_language" title="Koinē Greek language">Koinē Greek</a>: <span lang="grc">τὰ βιβλία</span>, <small>romanized: </small><span title="Koinē Greek-language romanization"><i lang="grc-x-koine-Latn">ta biblia</i></span>, meaning "the books" (singular <span title="Koinē Greek-language text"><span lang="grc">βιβλίον</span></span>, <span title="Koinē Greek-language romanization"><i lang="grc-x-koine-Latn">biblion</i></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBandstra20097Gravett_et_al.2008xv_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBandstra20097Gravett_et_al.2008xv-2">[2]</a></sup>
The word <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">βιβλίον</span></span> itself had the literal meaning of "<a href="/wiki/Scroll" title="Scroll">scroll</a>" and came to be used as the ordinary word for "book".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBeekes2009246–247_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBeekes2009246–247-3">[3]</a></sup> It is the diminutive of <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">βύβλος</span></span> <i>byblos</i>, "Egyptian papyrus", possibly so called from the name of the <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenician</a> sea port <a href="/wiki/Byblos" title="Byblos">Byblos</a> (also known as Gebal) from whence Egyptian <a href="/wiki/Papyrus" title="Papyrus">papyrus</a> was exported to Greece.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrake2008[httpsarchiveorgdetailsvisualhistoryofe00brakpage29_29]_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrake2008[httpsarchiveorgdetailsvisualhistoryofe00brakpage29_29]-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Greek <i>ta biblia</i> ("the books") was "an expression <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic_Jews" title="Hellenistic Jews">Hellenistic Jews</a> used to describe their sacred books".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> The biblical scholar <a href="/wiki/F._F._Bruce" title="F. F. Bruce">F. F. Bruce</a> notes that <a href="/wiki/John_Chrysostom" title="John Chrysostom">John Chrysostom</a> appears to be the first writer (in his <i>Homilies on Matthew</i>, delivered between 386 and 388) to use the Greek phrase <i>ta biblia</i> ("the books") to describe both the Old and New Testaments together.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBruce1988214_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBruce1988214-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Latin <i>biblia sacra</i> "holy books" translates Greek <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">τὰ βιβλία τὰ ἅγια</span></span> (<i>tà biblía tà hágia</i>, "the holy books").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">Medieval Latin</a> <span title="Medieval Latin-language text"><i lang="la">biblia</i></span> is short for <i>biblia sacra</i> "holy book". It gradually came to be regarded as a feminine singular noun (<span title="Medieval Latin-language text"><i lang="la">biblia</i></span>, gen. <span title="Medieval Latin-language text"><i lang="la">bibliae</i></span>) in medieval Latin, and so the word was loaned as singular into the vernaculars of Western Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Development_and_history">Development and history</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Biblical_manuscript" title="Biblical manuscript">Biblical manuscript</a>, <a href="/wiki/Textual_criticism" title="Textual criticism">Textual criticism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Samaritan_Pentateuch" title="Samaritan Pentateuch">Samaritan Pentateuch</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gutenberg_Bible,_Lenox_Copy,_New_York_Public_Library,_2009._Pic_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg/280px-Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg/420px-Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg/560px-Gutenberg_Bible%2C_Lenox_Copy%2C_New_York_Public_Library%2C_2009._Pic_01.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gutenberg_Bible,_Lenox_Copy,_New_York_Public_Library,_2009._Pic_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Gutenberg_Bible" title="Gutenberg Bible">Gutenberg Bible</a>, the first printed Bible (mid-15th century)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bible_from_1300_(20).jpg"><img alt="Hebrew Bible from 1300. Genesis." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3440" data-file-width="5848" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Bible_from_1300_%2820%29.jpg/220px-Bible_from_1300_%2820%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Bible_from_1300_%2820%29.jpg/330px-Bible_from_1300_%2820%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Bible_from_1300_%2820%29.jpg/440px-Bible_from_1300_%2820%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bible_from_1300_(20).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Hebrew Bible from 1300. Genesis.</div></div></div>
<p>The Bible is not a single book; it is a collection of books whose complex development is not completely understood. The oldest books began as songs and stories <a href="/wiki/Oral_tradition" title="Oral tradition">orally transmitted</a> from generation to generation. Scholars are just beginning to explore "the interface between writing, performance, memorization, and the aural dimension" of the texts. Current indications are that the ancient writing–reading process was supplemented by memorization and oral performance in community.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> The Bible was <a href="/wiki/Authorship_of_the_Bible" title="Authorship of the Bible">written and compiled by many people</a>, most of whom are unknown, from a variety of disparate cultures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESwenson202112Rogerson200521Riches2000ch._2_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwenson202112Rogerson200521Riches2000ch._2-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>British biblical scholar John K. Riches wrote:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERiches20009_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERiches20009-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>[T]he biblical texts were produced over a period in which the living conditions of the writers – political, cultural, economic, and ecological – varied enormously. There are texts which reflect a nomadic existence, texts from people with an established monarchy and Temple cult, texts from exile, texts born out of fierce oppression by foreign rulers, courtly texts, texts from wandering charismatic preachers, texts from those who give themselves the airs of sophisticated <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic</a> writers. It is a time-span which encompasses the compositions of <a href="/wiki/Homer" title="Homer">Homer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plato" title="Plato">Plato</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thucydides" title="Thucydides">Thucydides</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sophocles" title="Sophocles">Sophocles</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caesar" title="Caesar">Caesar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cicero" title="Cicero">Cicero</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catullus" title="Catullus">Catullus</a>. It is a period which sees the rise and fall of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assyrian_empire" title="Assyrian empire">Assyrian empire</a> (twelfth to seventh century) and of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_empire" title="Persian empire">Persian empire</a> (sixth to fourth century), <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander</a>'s campaigns (336–326), the rise of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Rome</a> and its domination of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean</a> (fourth century to the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Principate" title="Principate">Principate</a>, 27 <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">BCE</a>), the destruction of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">Jerusalem Temple</a> (70 CE), and the extension of Roman rule to parts of <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> (84 CE).</p></blockquote>
<p>The books of the Bible were initially written and copied by hand on <a href="/wiki/Papyrus" title="Papyrus">papyrus</a> scrolls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim20177,_47_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim20177,_47-12">[12]</a></sup> No originals survive. The age of the original composition of the texts is therefore difficult to determine and heavily debated. Using a combined linguistic and historiographical approach, Hendel and Joosten date the oldest parts of the Hebrew Bible (the Song of Deborah in Judges 5 and the Samson story of Judges 16 and 1 Samuel) to having been composed in the premonarchial early <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1200 BCE</span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHendelJoosten2018ix,_98–99,_101,_104,_106_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHendelJoosten2018ix,_98–99,_101,_104,_106-13">[13]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls" title="Dead Sea Scrolls">Dead Sea Scrolls</a>, discovered in the caves of <a href="/wiki/Qumran" title="Qumran">Qumran</a> in 1947, are copies that can be dated to between 250 BCE and 100 CE. They are the oldest existing copies of the books of the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> of any length that are not simply fragments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201738,_47Ulrich2013103–104VanderKamFlint2013ch._5Brown2010ch._3(A)HarrisPlatzner200822_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201738,_47Ulrich2013103–104VanderKamFlint2013ch._5Brown2010ch._3(A)HarrisPlatzner200822-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>The earliest manuscripts were probably written in <a href="/wiki/Paleo-Hebrew_alphabet" title="Paleo-Hebrew alphabet">paleo-Hebrew</a>, a kind of <a href="/wiki/Cuneiform" title="Cuneiform">cuneiform</a> pictograph similar to other pictographs of the same period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner200659_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner200659-15">[15]</a></sup> The exile to Babylon most likely prompted the shift to square script (Aramaic) in the fifth to third centuries BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner200660_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner200660-16">[16]</a></sup> From the time of the Dead Sea scrolls, the Hebrew Bible was written with spaces between words to aid in reading.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner200661_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner200661-17">[17]</a></sup> By the eighth century CE, the Masoretes added vowel signs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint201388–90_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint201388–90-18">[18]</a></sup> Levites or scribes maintained the texts, and some texts were always treated as more authoritative than others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner200662–63_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner200662–63-19">[19]</a></sup> Scribes preserved and changed the texts by changing the script and updating archaic forms while also making corrections. These Hebrew texts were copied with great care.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner200664–65_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner200664–65-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Samaritan_script_table.jpg"><img alt="chart comparing old Hebrew and Samaritan writing styles and letters" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1083" data-file-width="713" decoding="async" height="334" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Samaritan_script_table.jpg/220px-Samaritan_script_table.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Samaritan_script_table.jpg/330px-Samaritan_script_table.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Samaritan_script_table.jpg/440px-Samaritan_script_table.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Samaritan_script_table.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Hebrew-Samaritan script</div></div></div>
<p>Considered to be scriptures (<a href="/wiki/Sacredness" title="Sacredness">sacred</a>, authoritative religious texts), the books were compiled by different religious communities into various <a href="/wiki/Biblical_canon" title="Biblical canon">biblical canons</a> (official collections of scriptures).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHayes20129_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHayes20129-21">[21]</a></sup> The earliest compilation, containing the first five books of the Bible and called the <a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah">Torah</a> (meaning "law", "instruction", or "teaching") or Pentateuch ("five books"), was accepted as <a href="/wiki/Development_of_the_Hebrew_Bible_canon" title="Development of the Hebrew Bible canon">Jewish canon</a> by the 5th century BCE. A second collection of narrative histories and prophesies, called the <a href="/wiki/Nevi%27im" title="Nevi'im">Nevi'im</a> ("prophets"), was canonized in the 3rd century BCE. A third collection called the <a href="/wiki/Ketuvim" title="Ketuvim">Ketuvim</a> ("writings"), containing psalms, proverbs, and narrative histories, was canonized sometime between the 2nd century BCE and the 2nd century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHayes20129–10_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHayes20129–10-22">[22]</a></sup> These three collections were written mostly in <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Hebrew" title="Biblical Hebrew">Biblical Hebrew</a>, with some parts in <a href="/wiki/Aramaic" title="Aramaic">Aramaic</a>, which together form the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> or "TaNaKh" (an <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_abbreviations" title="Hebrew abbreviations">abbreviation</a> of "Torah", "Nevi'im", and "Ketuvim").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201740_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201740-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are three major <a href="/wiki/Biblical_manuscript" title="Biblical manuscript">historical versions</a> of the Hebrew Bible: the <a href="/wiki/Septuagint" title="Septuagint">Septuagint</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Masoretic_Text" title="Masoretic Text">Masoretic Text</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Samaritan_Pentateuch" title="Samaritan Pentateuch">Samaritan Pentateuch</a> (which contains only the first five books). They are related but do not share the same paths of development. The Septuagint, or the LXX, is a translation of the Hebrew scriptures, and some related texts, into Koine Greek, begun in <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> in the late 3rd century BCE and completed by 132 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESegal2010[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidowd9zig7i1oCpgPA363vonepage_363]_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESegal2010[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidowd9zig7i1oCpgPA363vonepage_363]-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDorivalHarlMunnich1988111_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDorivalHarlMunnich1988111-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ndq_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-ndq-26">[a]</a></sup> Probably commissioned by <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy_II_Philadelphus" title="Ptolemy II Philadelphus">Ptolemy II Philadelphus</a>, King of Egypt, it addressed the need of the primarily Greek-speaking Jews of the Graeco-Roman diaspora.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESegal2010[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidowd9zig7i1oCpgPA363vonepage_363]_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESegal2010[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidowd9zig7i1oCpgPA363vonepage_363]-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202130_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202130-27">[26]</a></sup> Existing complete copies of the Septuagint date from the 3rd to the 5th centuries CE, with fragments dating back to the 2nd century BCE. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201745–46,_58Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr2010250Bandstra20098,_480Gravett_et_al.200847HarrisPlatzner200827Riches2000ch._3_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201745–46,_58Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr2010250Bandstra20098,_480Gravett_et_al.200847HarrisPlatzner200827Riches2000ch._3-28">[27]</a></sup> Revision of its text began as far back as the first century BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dines_2004_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dines_2004-29">[28]</a></sup> Fragments of the Septuagint were found among the Dead Sea Scrolls; portions of its text are also found on existing papyrus from Egypt dating to the second and first centuries BCE and to the first century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dines_2004_29-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dines_2004-29">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 5">: 5 </span></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Masoretes" title="Masoretes">Masoretes</a> began developing what would become the authoritative <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Hebrew" title="Biblical Hebrew">Hebrew</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Aramaic" title="Biblical Aramaic">Aramaic</a> text of the 24 books of the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rabbinic_Judaism" title="Rabbinic Judaism">Rabbinic Judaism</a> near the end of the Talmudic period (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 300</span>–<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 500 CE</span>), but the actual date is difficult to determine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHauserWatsonKaufman200330–31_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHauserWatsonKaufman200330–31-30">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner1999[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidkkVFOTsBOAECq22Masoretesinherited22pgPA172_172]_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner1999[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidkkVFOTsBOAECq22Masoretesinherited22pgPA172_172]-31">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESwenson2021[httpswwwgooglecombooksid5xQOEAAAQBAJpgPA29_29]_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwenson2021[httpswwwgooglecombooksid5xQOEAAAQBAJpgPA29_29]-32">[31]</a></sup> In the sixth and seventh centuries, three Jewish communities contributed systems for writing the precise letter-text, with its <a href="/wiki/Niqqud" title="Niqqud">vocalization</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_cantillation" title="Hebrew cantillation">accentuation</a> known as the <i>mas'sora</i> (from which we derive the term "masoretic").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHauserWatsonKaufman200330–31_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHauserWatsonKaufman200330–31-30">[29]</a></sup> These early Masoretic scholars were based primarily in the Galilean cities of Tiberias and Jerusalem, and in Babylonia (modern Iraq). Those living in the Jewish community of Tiberias in ancient Galilee (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 750</span>–950), made scribal copies of the Hebrew Bible texts without a standard text, such as the Babylonian tradition had, to work from. The canonical pronunciation of the Hebrew Bible (called Tiberian Hebrew) that they developed, and many of the notes they made, therefore differed from the Babylonian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhillips2016288–291_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhillips2016288–291-33">[32]</a></sup> These differences were resolved into a standard text called the Masoretic text in the ninth century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202175_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202175-34">[33]</a></sup> The oldest complete copy still in existence is the <a href="/wiki/Leningrad_Codex" title="Leningrad Codex">Leningrad Codex</a> dating to c. 1000 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint201387_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint201387-35">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Samaritan Pentateuch is a version of the <a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah">Torah</a> maintained by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samaritan" title="Samaritan">Samaritan</a> community since antiquity, which was rediscovered by European scholars in the 17th century; its oldest existing copies date to c. 1100 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201746–49Ulrich201395–104VanderKamFlint2013ch._5Carr20108Bandstra2009482Gravett_et_al.200847–49HarrisPlatzner200823–28_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201746–49Ulrich201395–104VanderKamFlint2013ch._5Carr20108Bandstra2009482Gravett_et_al.200847–49HarrisPlatzner200823–28-36">[35]</a></sup> Samaritans include only the Pentateuch (Torah) in their biblical canon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint2013[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidSBMXnB4CRpUCpgPA91_91]_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint2013[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidSBMXnB4CRpUCpgPA91_91]-37">[36]</a></sup> They do not recognize <a href="/wiki/Authorship_of_the_Bible#Divine_authorship" title="Authorship of the Bible">divine authorship</a> or <a href="/wiki/Biblical_inspiration" title="Biblical inspiration">inspiration</a> in any other book in the Jewish Tanakh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[b]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Joshua_(Samaritan)" title="Book of Joshua (Samaritan)">Samaritan Book of Joshua</a> partly based upon the Tanakh's <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Joshua" title="Book of Joshua">Book of Joshua</a> exists, but Samaritans regard it as a non-canonical secular historical chronicle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaster1908[httpsbooksgooglecombooksideUCRAfZvwRgCpgPA166_166]_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaster1908[httpsbooksgooglecombooksideUCRAfZvwRgCpgPA166_166]-39">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the seventh century, the first <a href="/wiki/Codex" title="Codex">codex</a> form of the Hebrew Bible was produced. The codex is the forerunner of the modern book. Popularized by early Christians, it was made by folding a single sheet of papyrus in half, forming "pages". Assembling multiples of these folded pages together created a "book" that was more easily accessible and more portable than scrolls. In 1488, the first complete printed press version of the Hebrew Bible was produced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHauserWatsonKaufman200331–32_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHauserWatsonKaufman200331–32-40">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:File%22-Saint_Paul_Writing_His_Epistles%22_by_Valentin_de_Boulogne.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="445" data-file-width="599" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/File%22-Saint_Paul_Writing_His_Epistles%22_by_Valentin_de_Boulogne.jpg/220px-File%22-Saint_Paul_Writing_His_Epistles%22_by_Valentin_de_Boulogne.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/File%22-Saint_Paul_Writing_His_Epistles%22_by_Valentin_de_Boulogne.jpg/330px-File%22-Saint_Paul_Writing_His_Epistles%22_by_Valentin_de_Boulogne.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/File%22-Saint_Paul_Writing_His_Epistles%22_by_Valentin_de_Boulogne.jpg/440px-File%22-Saint_Paul_Writing_His_Epistles%22_by_Valentin_de_Boulogne.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:File%22-Saint_Paul_Writing_His_Epistles%22_by_Valentin_de_Boulogne.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Paul" title="Saint Paul">Saint Paul</a> Writing His <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Epistles" title="Epistles">Epistles</a></i>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1619</span> painting by <a href="/wiki/Valentin_de_Boulogne" title="Valentin de Boulogne">Valentin de Boulogne</a></div></div></div>
<p>During the rise of Christianity in the 1st century CE, new scriptures were written in Koine Greek. Christians called these new scriptures the "New Testament", and began referring to the Septuagint as the "Old Testament".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201745–46Brown2010Intro._and_ch._1Carr201017Bandstra20097,_484Riches2000chs._2_and_3_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201745–46Brown2010Intro._and_ch._1Carr201017Bandstra20097,_484Riches2000chs._2_and_3-41">[39]</a></sup> The New Testament has been preserved in more manuscripts than any other ancient work.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGurry2016117_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGurry2016117-42">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERezetkoYoung2014164_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERezetkoYoung2014164-43">[41]</a></sup> Most early Christian copyists were not trained scribes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner2006300_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner2006300-44">[42]</a></sup> Many copies of the gospels and Paul's letters were made by individual Christians over a relatively short period of time very soon after the originals were written.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWallace200988_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWallace200988-45">[43]</a></sup> There is evidence in the Synoptic Gospels, in the writings of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_church_fathers" title="Early church fathers">early church fathers</a>, from Marcion, and in the <a href="/wiki/Didache" title="Didache">Didache</a> that Christian documents were in circulation before the end of the first century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner200640–41,_300–301_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner200640–41,_300–301-46">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMowry194476,_84,_85_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMowry194476,_84,_85-47">[45]</a></sup> Paul's letters were circulated during his lifetime, and his death is thought to have occurred before 68 during Nero's reign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMowry194485_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMowry194485-48">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown1997436_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown1997436-49">[47]</a></sup> Early Christians transported these writings around the Empire, translating them into <a href="/wiki/Syriac_versions_of_the_Bible" title="Syriac versions of the Bible">Old Syriac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coptic_language" title="Coptic language">Coptic</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ge%27ez_language" title="Ge'ez language">Ethiopic</a>, and Latin, among other languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202129_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202129-50">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bart_Ehrman" title="Bart Ehrman">Bart Ehrman</a> explains how these multiple texts later became grouped by scholars into categories:</p><blockquote><p>during the early centuries of the church, Christian texts were copied in whatever location they were written or taken to. Since texts were copied locally, it is no surprise that different localities developed different kinds of textual tradition. That is to say, the manuscripts in Rome had many of the same errors, because they were for the most part "in-house" documents, copied from one another; they were not influenced much by manuscripts being copied in Palestine; and those in Palestine took on their own characteristics, which were not the same as those found in a place like Alexandria, Egypt. Moreover, in the early centuries of the church, some locales had better scribes than others. Modern scholars have come to recognize that the scribes in Alexandria – which was a major intellectual center in the ancient world – were particularly scrupulous, even in these early centuries, and that there, in Alexandria, a very pure form of the text of the early Christian writings was preserved, decade after decade, by dedicated and relatively skilled Christian scribes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[49]</a></sup></p></blockquote><p> These differing histories produced what modern scholars refer to as recognizable "text types". The four most commonly recognized are <a href="/wiki/Alexandrian_text-type" title="Alexandrian text-type">Alexandrian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_text-type" title="Western text-type">Western</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caesarean_text-type" title="Caesarean text-type">Caesarean</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_text-type" title="Byzantine text-type">Byzantine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParker2013412–420,_430–432Brown2010ch._3(A)_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParker2013412–420,_430–432Brown2010ch._3(A)-52">[50]</a></sup>
</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P52_verso.jpg"><img alt="photo of a fragment of papyrus with writing on it" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="549" data-file-width="349" decoding="async" height="283" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/P52_verso.jpg/180px-P52_verso.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/P52_verso.jpg/270px-P52_verso.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/49/P52_verso.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:P52_verso.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rylands_Library_Papyrus_P52" title="Rylands Library Papyrus P52">The Rylands fragment P52 verso</a> is the oldest existing fragment of New Testament papyrus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOrsiniClarysse2012470_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOrsiniClarysse2012470-53">[51]</a></sup> It contains phrases from the 18th chapter of the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_John" title="Gospel of John">Gospel of John</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The list of books included in the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Bible" title="Catholic Bible">Catholic Bible</a> was established as canon by the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Rome" title="Council of Rome">Council of Rome</a> in 382, followed by those of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Hippo" title="Council of Hippo">Hippo</a> in 393 and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Carthage#Synod_of_397" title="Council of Carthage">Carthage</a> in 397. Between 385 and 405 CE, the early Christian church translated its canon into <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">Vulgar Latin</a> (the common Latin spoken by ordinary people), a translation known as the <a href="/wiki/Vulgate" title="Vulgate">Vulgate</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201740Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr20103–5Bandstra20097–8,_480–481Gravett_et_al.2008xvHarrisPlatzner20083–4,_28,_371Riches2000ch._3_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201740Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr20103–5Bandstra20097–8,_480–481Gravett_et_al.2008xvHarrisPlatzner20083–4,_28,_371Riches2000ch._3-54">[52]</a></sup> Since then, Catholic Christians have held <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_council" title="Ecumenical council">ecumenical councils</a> to standardize their biblical canon. The <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a> (1545–63), held by the Catholic Church in response to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a>, authorized the Vulgate as its official Latin translation of the Bible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201740,_46,_49,_58–59Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr20103–5Bandstra20097–8,_480–481Gravett_et_al.2008xv,_49HarrisPlatzner20083–4,_28,_31–32,_371Riches2000ch._3_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201740,_46,_49,_58–59Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr20103–5Bandstra20097–8,_480–481Gravett_et_al.2008xv,_49HarrisPlatzner20083–4,_28,_31–32,_371Riches2000ch._3-55">[53]</a></sup> A number of biblical canons have since evolved. Christian biblical canons range from the 73 books of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a> canon, and the 66-book canon of most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> denominations, to the 81 books of the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church" title="Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church">Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church</a> canon, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERiches20007–8_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERiches20007–8-56">[54]</a></sup> Judaism has long accepted a single authoritative text, whereas Christianity has never had an official version, instead having many different manuscript traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton201915_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton201915-57">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>All biblical texts were treated with reverence and care by those that copied them, yet there are transmission errors, called variants, in all biblical manuscripts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner200641_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner200641-58">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlack199424_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlack199424-59">[57]</a></sup> A variant is simply any deviation between two texts. Textual critic Daniel B. Wallace explains that "Each deviation counts as one variant, regardless of how many MSS [manuscripts] attest to it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWallace200998_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWallace200998-60">[58]</a></sup> Hebrew scholar <a href="/wiki/Emanuel_Tov" title="Emanuel Tov">Emanuel Tov</a> says the term is not evaluative; it is simply a recognition that the paths of development of different texts have separated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETov200118_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETov200118-61">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>Medieval handwritten manuscripts of the Hebrew Bible were considered extremely precise: the most authoritative documents from which to copy other texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[60]</a></sup> Even so, <a href="/wiki/David_M._Carr" title="David M. Carr">David Carr</a> asserts that Hebrew texts contain both accidental and intentional types of variants: "memory variants" are generally accidental differences evidenced by such things as the shift in word order found in 1 Chronicles 17:24 and 2 Samuel 10:9 and 13. Variants also include the substitution of lexical equivalents, semantic and grammar differences, and larger scale shifts in order, with some major revisions of the Masoretic texts that must have been intentional.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarr20115–7,_18,_24,_29,_42,_55,_61,_145,_167_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarr20115–7,_18,_24,_29,_42,_55,_61,_145,_167-63">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>The majority of variants are accidental, such as spelling errors, but some changes were intentional.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlack199460_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlack199460-64">[62]</a></sup> Intentional changes in New Testament texts were made to improve grammar, eliminate discrepancies, harmonize parallel passages, combine and simplify multiple variant readings into one, and for theological reasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlack199460_64-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlack199460-64">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoyce2013461–464,_468,_470–473_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoyce2013461–464,_468,_470–473-65">[63]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Waltke" title="Bruce Waltke">Bruce K. Waltke</a> observes that one variant for every ten words was noted in the recent critical edition of the Hebrew Bible, the <i>Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia,</i> leaving 90% of the Hebrew text without variation. The fourth edition of the United Bible Society's <i>Greek New Testament</i> notes variants affecting about 500 out of 6900 words, or about 7% of the text.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWegner200625_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWegner200625-66">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Content_and_themes">Content and themes</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Themes">Themes</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ethics_in_the_Bible" title="Ethics in the Bible">Ethics in the Bible</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jewish_ethics" title="Jewish ethics">Jewish ethics</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Christian_ethics" title="Christian ethics">Christian ethics</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Creation_of_Light.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="646" data-file-width="513" decoding="async" height="277" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Creation_of_Light.png/220px-Creation_of_Light.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Creation_of_Light.png/330px-Creation_of_Light.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Creation_of_Light.png/440px-Creation_of_Light.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Creation_of_Light.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Creation of Light</i>, by <a href="/wiki/Gustave_Dor%C3%A9" title="Gustave Doré">Gustave Doré</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The narratives, laws, wisdom sayings, parables, and unique genrés of the Bible provide opportunity for discussion on most topics of concern to human beings: The role of women,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barbara_J._MacHaffie_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Barbara_J._MacHaffie-67">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 203">: 203 </span></sup> sex,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarper20131–14,_84–86,_88_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarper20131–14,_84–86,_88-68">[66]</a></sup> children, marriage,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chadwick_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chadwick-69">[67]</a></sup>  neighbors,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wayne_Grudem_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wayne_Grudem-70">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 24">: 24 </span></sup> friends, the nature of authority and the sharing of power,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 45–48">: 45–48 </span></sup> animals, trees and nature,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Northcott96_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-Northcott96-72">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: xi">: xi </span></sup>  money and economics,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hargaden_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hargaden-73">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 77">: 77 </span></sup> work, relationships,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kieran_Cronin_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kieran_Cronin-74">[72]</a></sup> sorrow and despair and the nature of joy, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGericke2012207_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGericke2012207-75">[73]</a></sup>  Philosopher and ethicist Jaco Gericke adds: "The meaning of good and evil, the nature of right and wrong, criteria for moral discernment, valid sources of morality, the origin and acquisition of moral beliefs, the ontological status of moral norms, moral authority, cultural pluralism, axiological and aesthetic assumptions about the nature of value and beauty. These are all implicit in the texts."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGericke2012210_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGericke2012210-76">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, discerning the themes of some biblical texts can be problematic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMittleman20121,_2_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMittleman20121,_2-77">[75]</a></sup> Much biblical narrative refrains from any kind of direct instruction, and in some texts the author's intent is not easy to decipher.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton20071–3_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton20071–3-78">[76]</a></sup> It is left to the reader to determine good and bad, right and wrong, and the path to understanding and practice is rarely straightforward.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton201914_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton201914-79">[77]</a></sup> God is sometimes portrayed as having a role in the plot, but more often there is little about God's reaction to events, and no mention at all of approval or disapproval of what the characters have done or failed to do.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton201940_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton201940-80">[78]</a></sup> The writer makes no comment, and the reader is left to infer what they will.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton201940_80-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton201940-80">[78]</a></sup> Jewish philosophers Shalom Carmy and David Schatz explain that the Bible "often juxtaposes contradictory ideas, without explanation or apology".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarmySchatz200313–14_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarmySchatz200313–14-81">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Hebrew Bible contains assumptions about the nature of knowledge, belief, truth, interpretation, understanding and cognitive processes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGericke2012209_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGericke2012209-82">[80]</a></sup> Ethicist <a href="/wiki/Michael_V._Fox" title="Michael V. Fox">Michael V. Fox</a> writes that the primary axiom of the book of Proverbs is that "the exercise of the human mind is the necessary and sufficient condition of right and successful behavior in all reaches of life".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFox200778_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFox200778-83">[81]</a></sup> The Bible teaches the nature of valid arguments, the nature and power of language, and its relation to reality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGericke2012210_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGericke2012210-76">[74]</a></sup> According to Mittleman, the Bible provides patterns of moral reasoning that focus on conduct and character.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton20193_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton20193-84">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMittleman201217_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMittleman201217-85">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the biblical metaphysic, humans have free will, but it is a relative and restricted freedom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrunner2002494_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrunner2002494-86">[84]</a></sup> Beach says that Christian <i>voluntarism</i> points to the <i>will</i> as the core of the self, and that within human nature, "the core of who we are is defined by what we love".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBeach198825–26_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBeach198825–26-87">[85]</a></sup> Natural law is in the Wisdom literature, the Prophets, Romans 1, Acts 17, and the book of Amos (Amos 1:3–2:5), where nations other than Israel are held accountable for their ethical decisions even though they don't know the Hebrew god.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton200348–50_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton200348–50-88">[86]</a></sup> Political theorist <a href="/wiki/Michael_Walzer" title="Michael Walzer">Michael Walzer</a> finds politics in the Hebrew Bible in covenant, law, and prophecy, which constitute an early form of <i>almost</i> democratic political ethics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWalzer2012200_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWalzer2012200-89">[87]</a></sup> Key elements in biblical criminal justice begin with the belief in God as the source of justice and the judge of all, including those administering justice on earth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESouryal2015xx_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESouryal2015xx-90">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>Carmy and Schatz say the Bible "depicts the character of God, presents an account of creation, posits a metaphysics of divine providence and divine intervention, suggests a basis for morality, discusses many features of human nature, and frequently poses the notorious conundrum of how God can allow evil."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarmySchatz200313,_14_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarmySchatz200313,_14-91">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hebrew_Bible">Hebrew Bible</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> and <a href="/wiki/Development_of_the_Hebrew_Bible_canon" title="Development of the Hebrew Bible canon">Development of the Hebrew Bible canon</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile nowraplinks plainlist" style="line-height:1.4em;"><tbody><tr><th class="sidebar-title"><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tanakh" title="Tanakh">Tanakh</a></i></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image" style="padding-bottom:0.8em;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aleppo_Codex_Joshua_1_1.jpg" title="Joshua 1:1 as recorded in the Aleppo Codex"><img alt="Joshua 1:1 as recorded in the Aleppo Codex" data-file-height="366" data-file-width="743" decoding="async" height="89" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Aleppo_Codex_Joshua_1_1.jpg/180px-Aleppo_Codex_Joshua_1_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Aleppo_Codex_Joshua_1_1.jpg/270px-Aleppo_Codex_Joshua_1_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Aleppo_Codex_Joshua_1_1.jpg/360px-Aleppo_Codex_Joshua_1_1.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah"><span style="font-size:110%"><i>Torah</i></span> <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047488">.mw-parser-output .nobold{font-weight:normal}</style><span class="nobold">(Instruction)</span></a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content" style="border-top:1px solid #aaa;border-bottom:1px solid #aaa;"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1066479718">.mw-parser-output .infobox-subbox{padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .infobox-3cols-child{margin:auto}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-header,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-subheader,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-above,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-title,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-image,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-below{text-align:center}</style><table class="infobox" style="background-color: transparent; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border:none; width:100%; margin:0px; font-size:100%; clear:none; float:none;width:11.5em;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;line-height:1.2em;white-space:nowrap;"><tbody><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Genesis" title="Book of Genesis">Genesis</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Bereshit</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Exodus" title="Book of Exodus">Exodus</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Shemot</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Leviticus" title="Book of Leviticus">Leviticus</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Wayiqra</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Numbers" title="Book of Numbers">Numbers</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Bemidbar</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Deuteronomy" title="Book of Deuteronomy">Deuteronomy</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Devarim</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Nevi%27im" title="Nevi'im"><span style="font-size:110%"><i>Nevi'im</i></span> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(Prophets)</span></a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content" style="border-top:1px solid #aaa;border-bottom:1px solid #aaa;"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar nomobile nowraplinks" style="background-color: transparent; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border:none; width:100%; margin:0px; font-size:100%; clear:none; float:none"><tbody><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="text-align:center;">
<a href="/wiki/Nevi%27im#Former_Prophets" title="Nevi'im">Former</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066479718" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="infobox" style="background-color: transparent; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border:none; width:100%; margin:0px; font-size:100%; clear:none; float:none;width:10.0em;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;line-height:1.2em;white-space:nowrap;"><tbody><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Joshua" title="Book of Joshua">Joshua</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Yehoshua</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Judges" title="Book of Judges">Judges</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Shofetim</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Books_of_Samuel" title="Books of Samuel">Samuel</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Shemuel</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Books_of_Kings" title="Books of Kings">Kings</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Melakhim</td></tr></tbody></table></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="text-align:center;">
<a href="/wiki/Nevi%27im#Latter_Prophets" title="Nevi'im">Latter</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066479718" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="infobox" style="background-color: transparent; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border:none; width:100%; margin:0px; font-size:100%; clear:none; float:none;width:10.0em;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;line-height:1.2em;white-space:nowrap;"><tbody><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Isaiah" title="Book of Isaiah">Isaiah</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Yeshayahu</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Jeremiah" title="Book of Jeremiah">Jeremiah</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Yirmeyahu</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Ezekiel" title="Book of Ezekiel">Ezekiel</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Yekhezqel</td></tr></tbody></table></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="text-align:center;">
<a href="/wiki/Twelve_Minor_Prophets" title="Twelve Minor Prophets">Minor </a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="hlist hlist-separated" style="padding-top:0.15em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Hosea" title="Book of Hosea">Hosea</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Joel" title="Book of Joel">Joel</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Amos" title="Book of Amos">Amos</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Obadiah" title="Book of Obadiah">Obadiah</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Jonah" title="Book of Jonah">Jonah</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Micah" title="Book of Micah">Micah</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Nahum" title="Book of Nahum">Nahum</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Habakkuk" title="Book of Habakkuk">Habakkuk</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Zephaniah" title="Book of Zephaniah">Zephaniah</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Haggai" title="Book of Haggai">Haggai</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Zechariah" title="Book of Zechariah">Zechariah</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Malachi" title="Book of Malachi">Malachi</a></li></ul>
</div></td>
</tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Ketuvim" title="Ketuvim"><span style="font-size:110%"><i>Ketuvim</i></span> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(Writings)</span></a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content" style="border-top:1px solid #aaa;border-bottom:1px solid #aaa;"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar nomobile nowraplinks" style="background-color: transparent; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border:none; width:100%; margin:0px; font-size:100%; clear:none; float:none"><tbody><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="text-align:center;">
Poetic</th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066479718" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="infobox" style="background-color: transparent; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border:none; width:100%; margin:0px; font-size:100%; clear:none; float:none;width:15.5em;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;line-height:1.2em;white-space:nowrap;"><tbody><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Psalms" title="Psalms">Psalms</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Tehillim</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Proverbs" title="Book of Proverbs">Proverbs</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Mishlei</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Job" title="Book of Job">Job</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Iyov</td></tr></tbody></table></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="text-align:center;">
<a href="/wiki/Five_Megillot" title="Five Megillot">Five <i>Megillot</i> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(Scrolls)</span></a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066479718" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="infobox" style="background-color: transparent; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border:none; width:100%; margin:0px; font-size:100%; clear:none; float:none;width:15.5em;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;line-height:1.2em;white-space:nowrap;"><tbody><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Song_of_Songs" title="Song of Songs">Song of Songs</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Shir Hashirim</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Ruth" title="Book of Ruth">Ruth</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Rut</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Lamentations" title="Book of Lamentations">Lamentations</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Eikhah</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastes" title="Ecclesiastes">Ecclesiastes</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Qohelet</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Esther" title="Book of Esther">Esther</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Ester</td></tr></tbody></table></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="text-align:center;">
Historical</th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066479718" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="infobox" style="background-color: transparent; border-collapse:collapse; border-spacing:0px; border:none; width:100%; margin:0px; font-size:100%; clear:none; float:none;width:15.5em;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;line-height:1.2em;white-space:nowrap;"><tbody><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Daniel" title="Book of Daniel">Daniel</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Daniyyel</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Ezra%E2%80%93Nehemiah" title="Ezra–Nehemiah">Ezra–Nehemiah</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Ezra</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Books_of_Chronicles" title="Books of Chronicles">Chronicles</a></th><td class="infobox-data" style="text-align:right;font-style:italic;">Divre Hayyamim</td></tr></tbody></table></td>
</tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Tanakh" title="Template:Tanakh"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Tanakh" title="Template talk:Tanakh"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Tanakh&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The authoritative Hebrew Bible is taken from the masoretic text (called the <a href="/wiki/Leningrad_Codex" title="Leningrad Codex">Leningrad Codex</a>) which dates from 1008. The Hebrew Bible can therefore sometimes be referred to as the Masoretic Text.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Hebrew Bible is also known by the name Tanakh (<a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020748213">.mw-parser-output .script-hebrew,.mw-parser-output .script-Hebr{font-family:"SBL Hebrew","SBL BibLit","Taamey Ashkenaz","Taamey Frank CLM","Frank Ruehl CLM","Ezra SIL","Ezra SIL SR","Keter Aram Tsova","Taamey David CLM","Keter YG","Shofar","David CLM","Hadasim CLM","Simple CLM","Nachlieli",Cardo,Alef,"Noto Serif Hebrew","Noto Sans Hebrew","David Libre",David,"Times New Roman",Gisha,Arial,FreeSerif,FreeSans}</style><span class="script-hebrew" dir="rtl" style="font-size: 115%;">תנ"ך</span>‎). This reflects the threefold division of the Hebrew scriptures, <a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah">Torah</a> ("Teaching"), <a href="/wiki/Nevi%27im" title="Nevi'im">Nevi'im</a> ("Prophets") and <a href="/wiki/Ketuvim" title="Ketuvim">Ketuvim</a> ("Writings") by using the first letters of each word.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetzger_&amp;_Katz2010651,_footnote_1_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetzger_&amp;_Katz2010651,_footnote_1-93">[91]</a></sup> It is not until the Babylonian Talmud (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 550 BCE</span>) that a listing of the contents of these three divisions of scripture are found.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPace2016354_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPace2016354-94">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Tanakh was mainly written in <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Hebrew" title="Biblical Hebrew">Biblical Hebrew</a>, with some small portions (Ezra 4:8–6:18 and 7:12–26, Jeremiah 10:11, Daniel 2:4–7:28)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[93]</a></sup> written in <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Aramaic" title="Biblical Aramaic">Biblical Aramaic</a>, a language which had become the <i><a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a></i> for much of the Semitic world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Driver_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-Driver-96">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Torah">Torah</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah">Torah</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Oral_Torah" title="Oral Torah">Oral Torah</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ln-Tora-und-Innenansicht-Synagoge-Glockengasse-040.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2040" data-file-width="1496" decoding="async" height="300" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/K%C3%B6ln-Tora-und-Innenansicht-Synagoge-Glockengasse-040.JPG/220px-K%C3%B6ln-Tora-und-Innenansicht-Synagoge-Glockengasse-040.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/K%C3%B6ln-Tora-und-Innenansicht-Synagoge-Glockengasse-040.JPG/330px-K%C3%B6ln-Tora-und-Innenansicht-Synagoge-Glockengasse-040.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/K%C3%B6ln-Tora-und-Innenansicht-Synagoge-Glockengasse-040.JPG/440px-K%C3%B6ln-Tora-und-Innenansicht-Synagoge-Glockengasse-040.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ln-Tora-und-Innenansicht-Synagoge-Glockengasse-040.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Torah_scroll" title="Torah scroll">Torah scroll</a> recovered from <a href="/wiki/Glockengasse_Synagogue" title="Glockengasse Synagogue">Glockengasse Synagogue</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cologne" title="Cologne">Cologne</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Torah (תּוֹרָה) is also known as the "Five Books of <a href="/wiki/Moses" title="Moses">Moses</a>" or the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pentateuch" title="Pentateuch">Pentateuch</a>, meaning "five scroll-cases".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarnstone2009[[iarchive:isbn_9780393064933/page/647|647]]_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarnstone2009[[iarchive:isbn_9780393064933/page/647|647]]-97">[95]</a></sup> Traditionally these books were considered to have been <a href="/wiki/Mosaic_authorship" title="Mosaic authorship">dictated to Moses</a> by God himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinson200697_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinson200697-98">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone20051072_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrossLivingstone20051072-99">[97]</a></sup> Since the 17th century, scholars have viewed the original sources as being the product of multiple anonymous authors while also allowing the possibility that Moses first assembled the separate sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENahkola2007vii,_xvi,_197,_204,_216–217_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENahkola2007vii,_xvi,_197,_204,_216–217-100">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBaden201213_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaden201213-101">[99]</a></sup> There are a variety of hypotheses regarding when and how <a href="/wiki/Composition_of_the_Torah" title="Composition of the Torah">the Torah was composed</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreifenhagen2003206_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreifenhagen2003206-102">[100]</a></sup> but there is a general consensus that it took its final form during the reign of the Persian <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> (probably 450–350 BCE),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreifenhagen2003206–207_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreifenhagen2003206–207-103">[101]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENewsom200426_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENewsom200426-104">[102]</a></sup> or perhaps in the early <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic period</a> (333–164 BCE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreifenhagen2003224_n._49_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreifenhagen2003224_n._49-105">[103]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Samaritan_Inscription_containing_portion_of_the_Bible_in_nine_lines_of_Hebrew_text,_currently_housed_in_the_British_Museum.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4420" data-file-width="4016" decoding="async" height="242" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Samaritan_Inscription_containing_portion_of_the_Bible_in_nine_lines_of_Hebrew_text%2C_currently_housed_in_the_British_Museum.jpg/220px-Samaritan_Inscription_containing_portion_of_the_Bible_in_nine_lines_of_Hebrew_text%2C_currently_housed_in_the_British_Museum.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Samaritan_Inscription_containing_portion_of_the_Bible_in_nine_lines_of_Hebrew_text%2C_currently_housed_in_the_British_Museum.jpg/330px-Samaritan_Inscription_containing_portion_of_the_Bible_in_nine_lines_of_Hebrew_text%2C_currently_housed_in_the_British_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Samaritan_Inscription_containing_portion_of_the_Bible_in_nine_lines_of_Hebrew_text%2C_currently_housed_in_the_British_Museum.jpg/440px-Samaritan_Inscription_containing_portion_of_the_Bible_in_nine_lines_of_Hebrew_text%2C_currently_housed_in_the_British_Museum.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Samaritan_Inscription_containing_portion_of_the_Bible_in_nine_lines_of_Hebrew_text,_currently_housed_in_the_British_Museum.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Samaritan Inscription containing portion of the Bible in nine lines of Hebrew text, currently housed in the British Museum</div></div></div>
<p>The Hebrew names of the books are derived from the <a href="/wiki/Incipit" title="Incipit">first words</a> in the respective texts. The Torah consists of the following five books:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Genesis" title="Book of Genesis">Genesis</a>, <i>Beresheeth</i> (בראשית)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Exodus" title="Book of Exodus">Exodus</a>, <i>Shemot</i> (שמות)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Leviticus" title="Book of Leviticus">Leviticus</a>, <i>Vayikra</i> (ויקרא)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Numbers" title="Book of Numbers">Numbers</a>, <i>Bamidbar</i> (במדבר)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Deuteronomy" title="Book of Deuteronomy">Deuteronomy</a>, <i>Devarim</i> (דברים)</li></ul>
<p>The first eleven chapters of Genesis provide accounts of the <a href="/wiki/Genesis_creation_narrative" title="Genesis creation narrative">creation</a> (or ordering) of the world and the history of God's early relationship with humanity. The remaining thirty-nine chapters of Genesis provide an account of God's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biblical_covenant" title="Biblical covenant">covenant</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Patriarchs_(Bible)" title="Patriarchs (Bible)">biblical patriarchs</a> <a href="/wiki/Abraham" title="Abraham">Abraham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isaac" title="Isaac">Isaac</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jacob" title="Jacob">Jacob</a> (also called <a href="/wiki/Israel_(name)" title="Israel (name)">Israel</a>) and Jacob's children, the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Children_of_Israel" title="Children of Israel">Children of Israel</a>", especially <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joseph_(Hebrew_Bible)" title="Joseph (Hebrew Bible)">Joseph</a>. It tells of how God commanded Abraham to leave his family and home in the city of <a href="/wiki/Ur_of_the_Chaldees" title="Ur of the Chaldees">Ur</a>, eventually to settle in the land of <a href="/wiki/Canaan" title="Canaan">Canaan</a>, and how the Children of Israel later moved to Egypt.
</p><p>The remaining four books of the Torah tell the story of <a href="/wiki/Moses" title="Moses">Moses</a>, who lived hundreds of years after the patriarchs. He leads the Children of Israel from slavery in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a> to the renewal of their covenant with God at <a href="/wiki/Mount_Sinai_(Bible)" title="Mount Sinai (Bible)">Mount Sinai</a> and their wanderings in the desert until a new generation was ready to enter the land of Canaan. The Torah ends with the death of Moses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERossel2007[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidAzZlANCOIRgCpgpa355vonepage_355]_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERossel2007[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidAzZlANCOIRgCpgpa355vonepage_355]-106">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>The commandments in the Torah provide the basis for <a href="/wiki/Halakha" title="Halakha">Jewish religious law</a>. Tradition states that there are <a href="/wiki/613_commandments" title="613 commandments">613 commandments</a> (<i>taryag mitzvot</i>).
</p>
<h4><span id="Nevi.27im"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Nevi'im">Nevi'im</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Nevi%27im" title="Nevi'im">Nevi'im</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar nomobile nowraplinks"><tbody><tr><th class="sidebar-title nowrap" style="background:#ccccff;font-size:120%;">Books of <a href="/wiki/Nevi%27im" title="Nevi'im">Nevi'im</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content plainlist" style="padding-top:0.15em;padding-bottom:0.5em;;font-size:50%;line-height:0.5em;">
 </td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background:#ddddff;">
Former Prophets</th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content plainlist" style="padding-top:0.15em;padding-bottom:0.5em;">
<div class="hlist hlist-separated">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Joshua" title="Book of Joshua">Joshua</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Judges" title="Book of Judges">Judges</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Books_of_Samuel" title="Books of Samuel">Samuel</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Books_of_Kings" title="Books of Kings">Kings</a></li></ul>
</div></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background:#ddddff;">

<div class="hlist hlist-separated">
