<td style="text-indent:1em"><span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">Μακκαβαίων Δ' Παράρτημα</span></span></td>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IV_Maccabees" title="IV Maccabees">IV Makkabees</a></td>
<td>4 Maccabees<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[w]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="New_Testament">New Testament</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Development_of_the_New_Testament_canon" title="Development of the New Testament canon">Development of the New Testament canon</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Testament_apocrypha" title="New Testament apocrypha">New Testament apocrypha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antilegomena" title="Antilegomena">Antilegomena</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Language_of_the_New_Testament" title="Language of the New Testament">Language of the New Testament</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Category:New_Testament_content" title="Category:New Testament content">Category:New Testament content</a></div>
<p>The New Testament is the name given to the second portion of the Christian Bible. While some scholars assert that Aramaic was the original language of the New Testament,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Erbes_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-Erbes-173">[150]</a></sup> the majority view says it was written in the vernacular form of Koine Greek. Still, there is reason to assert that it is a heavily Semitized Greek: its syntax is like conversational Greek, but its style is largely Semitic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWallace199625–29_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWallace199625–29-174">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[x]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[y]</a></sup> Koina Greek was the <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">common language</a> of the western Roman Empire from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conquests_of_Alexander_the_Great" title="Conquests of Alexander the Great">Conquests of Alexander the Great</a> (335–323 BCE) until the evolution of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine_Greek" title="Byzantine Greek">Byzantine Greek</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 600</span>) while Aramaic was the language of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a>, the Apostles and the ancient Near East.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Erbes_173-1"><a href="#cite_note-Erbes-173">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[z]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[aa]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[ab]</a></sup> The term "New Testament" came into use in the second century during a controversy over whether the Hebrew Bible should be included with the Christian writings as sacred scripture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton19983,_4,_7_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton19983,_4,_7-180">[152]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Marinus_Claesz._van_Reymerswaele_002.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2311" data-file-width="3051" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Marinus_Claesz._van_Reymerswaele_002.jpg/220px-Marinus_Claesz._van_Reymerswaele_002.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Marinus_Claesz._van_Reymerswaele_002.jpg/330px-Marinus_Claesz._van_Reymerswaele_002.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Marinus_Claesz._van_Reymerswaele_002.jpg/440px-Marinus_Claesz._van_Reymerswaele_002.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Marinus_Claesz._van_Reymerswaele_002.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>St. Jerome in His Study</i>, by <a href="/wiki/Marinus_van_Reymerswaele" title="Marinus van Reymerswaele">Marinus van Reymerswaele</a>, 1541. <a href="/wiki/Jerome" title="Jerome">Jerome</a> produced a 4th-century <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> edition of the Bible, known as the Vulgate, that became the Catholic Church's official translation.</div></div></div>
<p>It is generally accepted that the New Testament writers were Jews who took the inspiration of the Old Testament for granted. This is probably stated earliest in <span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2Tim+3%3A16&amp;version=9" rel="nofollow">2 Timothy 3:16</a></span>: "All scripture is given by inspiration of God". Scholarship on how and why ancient Jewish–Christians came to create and accept new texts as equal to the established Hebrew texts has taken three forms. First, <a href="/wiki/John_Barton_(theologian)" title="John Barton (theologian)">John Barton</a> writes that ancient Christians probably just continued the Jewish tradition of writing and incorporating what they believed were inspired, authoritative religious books.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton19982_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton19982-181">[153]</a></sup> The second approach separates those various inspired writings based on a concept of "canon" which developed in the second century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton19983–8_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton19983–8-182">[154]</a></sup> The third involves formalizing canon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton19988–11_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton19988–11-183">[155]</a></sup> According to Barton, these differences are only differences in terminology; the ideas are reconciled if they are seen as three stages in the formation of the New Testament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton199811,_14–19_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton199811,_14–19-184">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first stage was completed remarkably early if one accepts <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Albert_C._Sundberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Albert C. Sundberg (page does not exist)">Albert C. Sundberg</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;"> [<a class="extiw" href="https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_C._Sundberg" title="de:Albert C. Sundberg">de</a>]</span>'s view that "canon" and "scripture" are separate things, with "scripture" having been recognized by ancient Christians long before "canon" was.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton19989–11,_17–18_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton19989–11,_17–18-185">[157]</a></sup> Barton says <a href="/wiki/Theodor_Zahn" title="Theodor Zahn">Theodor Zahn</a> concluded "there was already a Christian canon by the end of the first century", but this is not the canon of later centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton19983_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton19983-186">[158]</a></sup> Accordingly, Sundberg asserts that in the first centuries, there was no criterion for inclusion in the "sacred writings" beyond inspiration, and that no one in the first century had the idea of a closed canon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton19989–11_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton19989–11-187">[159]</a></sup> The gospels were accepted by early believers as handed down from those Apostles who had known Jesus and been taught by him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKelly2000[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidUivDgM0WywoCpgPA4vonepage_4]_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKelly2000[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidUivDgM0WywoCpgPA4vonepage_4]-188">[160]</a></sup> Later biblical criticism has questioned the authorship and datings of the gospels.
</p><p>At the end of the second century, it is widely recognized that a Christian canon similar to its modern version was asserted by the church fathers in response to the <a href="/wiki/List_of_early_Christian_texts_of_disputed_authorship" title="List of early Christian texts of disputed authorship">plethora of writings</a> claiming inspiration that contradicted <a href="/wiki/Orthodoxy" title="Orthodoxy">orthodoxy</a>: (<a href="/wiki/Heresy_in_Christianity" title="Heresy in Christianity">heresy</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton19987_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton19987-189">[161]</a></sup> The third stage of development as the final canon occurred in the fourth century with a series of <a href="/wiki/Synod" title="Synod">synods</a> that produced a list of texts of the canon of the Old Testament and the New Testament that are still used today. Most notably the <a href="/wiki/Synod_of_Hippo" title="Synod of Hippo">Synod of Hippo</a> in 393 CE and that of <i>c</i>. 400. Jerome produced a definitive Latin edition of the Bible (the <a href="/wiki/Vulgate" title="Vulgate">Vulgate</a>), the canon of which, at the insistence of the Pope, was in accord with the earlier Synods. This process effectively set the New Testament canon.
</p><p>New Testament books already had considerable authority in the late first and early second centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton199814_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton199814-190">[162]</a></sup> Even in its formative period, most of the books of the NT that were seen as scripture were already agreed upon. Linguistics scholar <a href="/wiki/Stanley_E._Porter" title="Stanley E. Porter">Stanley E. Porter</a> says "evidence from the apocryphal non-Gospel literature is the same as that for the apocryphal Gospels – in other words, that the text of the Greek New Testament was relatively well established and fixed by the time of the second and third centuries".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPorter2011198_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPorter2011198-191">[163]</a></sup> By the time the fourth century Fathers were approving the "canon", they were doing little more than codifying what was already universally accepted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton199815_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton199815-192">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p>The New Testament is a collection of 27 books<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMears2007[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidm2Lz7iwklhACpgPA439vonepage_438–439]_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMears2007[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidm2Lz7iwklhACpgPA439vonepage_438–439]-193">[165]</a></sup> of 4 different <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Genres" title="Genres">genres</a> of Christian literature (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gospels" title="Gospels">Gospels</a>, one account of the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Epistles" title="Epistles">Epistles</a> and an <a href="/wiki/Apocalyptic_literature" title="Apocalyptic literature">Apocalypse</a>). These books can be grouped into:
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Gospel" title="Gospel">The Gospels</a> are narratives of Jesus' last three years of life, his death and resurrection.
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Synoptic_Gospels" title="Synoptic Gospels">Synoptic Gospels</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Gospel of Matthew</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Mark" title="Gospel of Mark">Gospel of Mark</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Luke" title="Gospel of Luke">Gospel of Luke</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_John" title="Gospel of John">Gospel of John</a></li></ul>
<p><a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles_(genre)" title="Acts of the Apostles (genre)">Narrative literature</a>, provide an account and history of the very early Apostolic age.
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles" title="Acts of the Apostles">Acts of the Apostles</a></li></ul>
<p><a href="/wiki/Pauline_epistles" title="Pauline epistles">Pauline epistles</a> are written to individual church groups to address problems, provide encouragement and give instruction.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r998391716">.mw-parser-output .div-col{margin-top:0.3em;column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .div-col-small{font-size:90%}.mw-parser-output .div-col-rules{column-rule:1px solid #aaa}.mw-parser-output .div-col dl,.mw-parser-output .div-col ol,.mw-parser-output .div-col ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .div-col li,.mw-parser-output .div-col dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 18em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Romans" title="Epistle to the Romans">Epistle to the Romans</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_to_the_Corinthians" title="First Epistle to the Corinthians">First Epistle to the Corinthians</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Second_Epistle_to_the_Corinthians" title="Second Epistle to the Corinthians">Second Epistle to the Corinthians</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Galatians" title="Epistle to the Galatians">Epistle to the Galatians</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Ephesians" title="Epistle to the Ephesians">Epistle to the Ephesians</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Philippians" title="Epistle to the Philippians">Epistle to the Philippians</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Colossians" title="Epistle to the Colossians">Epistle to the Colossians</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_to_the_Thessalonians" title="First Epistle to the Thessalonians">First Epistle to the Thessalonians</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Second_Epistle_to_the_Thessalonians" title="Second Epistle to the Thessalonians">Second Epistle to the Thessalonians</a></li></ul>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Pastoral_epistles" title="Pastoral epistles">Pastoral epistles</a> discuss the pastoral oversight of churches, Christian living, doctrine and leadership.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 18em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_to_Timothy" title="First Epistle to Timothy">First Epistle to Timothy</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Second_Epistle_to_Timothy" title="Second Epistle to Timothy">Second Epistle to Timothy</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_Titus" title="Epistle to Titus">Epistle to Titus</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_Philemon" title="Epistle to Philemon">Epistle to Philemon</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_to_the_Hebrews" title="Epistle to the Hebrews">Epistle to the Hebrews</a></li></ul>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Catholic_epistles" title="Catholic epistles">Catholic epistles</a>, also called the general epistles or lesser epistles.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 18em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_of_James" title="Epistle of James">Epistle of James</a> encourages a lifestyle consistent with faith.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_of_Peter" title="First Epistle of Peter">First Epistle of Peter</a> addresses trial and suffering.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Second_Epistle_of_Peter" title="Second Epistle of Peter">Second Epistle of Peter</a> more on suffering's purposes, Christology, ethics and eschatology.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/First_Epistle_of_John" title="First Epistle of John">First Epistle of John</a> covers how to discern true Christians: by their ethics, their proclamation of Jesus in the flesh, and by their love.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Second_Epistle_of_John" title="Second Epistle of John">Second Epistle of John</a> warns against <a href="/wiki/Docetism" title="Docetism">docetism</a>.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Third_Epistle_of_John" title="Third Epistle of John">Third Epistle of John</a> encourage, strengthen and warn.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Epistle_of_Jude" title="Epistle of Jude">Epistle of Jude</a> condemns opponents.</li></ul>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Apocalyptic_literature" title="Apocalyptic literature">Apocalyptic literature</a>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Revelation" title="Book of Revelation">Book of Revelation</a>, or the Apocalypse, predicts end time events.</li></ul>
<p>Both Catholics and Protestants (as well as Greek Orthodox) currently have the same 27-book New Testament Canon. They are ordered differently in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slavonic_translations_of_the_Bible" title="Slavonic translations of the Bible">Slavonic tradition</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Syriac_versions_of_the_Bible" title="Syriac versions of the Bible">Syriac</a> tradition and the Ethiopian tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlinn2007[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidgxEONS0FFlsCpgPA103vonepage_103]_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlinn2007[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidgxEONS0FFlsCpgPA103vonepage_103]-194">[166]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Canon_variations">Canon variations</span></h4>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Peshitta">Peshitta</span></h5>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Peshitta" title="Peshitta">Peshitta</a></div>
<p>The Peshitta (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classical_Syriac_language" title="Classical Syriac language">Classical Syriac</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="syc">ܦܫܺܝܛܬܳܐ</span> <i>or</i> <span title="Classical Syriac-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="syc">ܦܫܝܼܛܬܵܐ</span></span> <i><span title="Classical Syriac-language romanization"><i lang="syc-Latn">pšīṭtā</i></span></i>) is the standard version of the Bible for churches in the <a href="/wiki/Syriac_Christianity" title="Syriac Christianity">Syriac tradition</a>. The consensus within biblical scholarship, although not universal, is that the Old Testament of the Peshitta was translated into <a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac</a> from <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Hebrew" title="Biblical Hebrew">biblical Hebrew</a>, probably in the 2nd century CE, and that the New Testament of the Peshitta was translated from the Greek.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[ac]</a></sup> This New Testament, originally excluding certain <a href="/wiki/Antilegomena" title="Antilegomena">disputed books</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2_Peter" title="2 Peter">2 Peter</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2_John" title="2 John">2 John</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/3_John" title="3 John">3 John</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epistle_of_Jude" title="Epistle of Jude">Jude</a>, <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Revelation" title="Book of Revelation">Revelation</a>), had become a standard by the early 5th century. The five excluded books were added in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harklean_Version" title="Harklean Version">Harklean Version</a> (616 CE) of <a href="/wiki/Thomas_of_Harqel" title="Thomas of Harqel">Thomas of Harqel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bromiley1995_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bromiley1995-196">[ad]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Erbes_173-2"><a href="#cite_note-Erbes-173">[150]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Catholic_Church_canon">Catholic Church canon</span></h5>
<p>The canon of the Catholic Church was affirmed by the Council of Rome (AD 382), the Synod of Hippo (in AD 393), the Council of Carthage (AD 397), the Council of Carthage (AD 419), the Council of Florence (AD 1431–1449) and finally, as an article of faith, by the Council of Trent (AD 1545–1563) establishing the canon consisting of 46 books in the Old Testament and 27 books in the New Testament for a total of 73 books in the Catholic Bible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERüger1989302_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERüger1989302-197">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[ae]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethiopian_Orthodox_canon">Ethiopian Orthodox canon</span></h5>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Tewahedo_biblical_canon" title="Orthodox Tewahedo biblical canon">Orthodox Tewahedo biblical canon</a></div>
<p>The canon of the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church" title="Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church">Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church</a> is wider than the canons used by most other Christian churches. There are 81 books in the Ethiopian Orthodox Bible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethiopian_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ethiopian-201">[170]</a></sup> In addition to the books found in the <a href="/wiki/Septuagint" title="Septuagint">Septuagint</a> accepted by other Orthodox Christians, the Ethiopian Old Testament Canon uses <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Enoch" title="Book of Enoch">Enoch</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jubilees" title="Jubilees">Jubilees</a> (ancient Jewish books that only survived in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ge%27ez_language" title="Ge'ez language">Ge'ez</a>, but are quoted in the New Testament),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReinhartz202119_156-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReinhartz202119-156">[141]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/1_Esdras" title="1 Esdras">Greek Ezra</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_Apocalypse_of_Ezra" title="Jewish Apocalypse of Ezra">Apocalypse of Ezra</a>, 3 books of <a href="/wiki/Meqabyan" title="Meqabyan">Meqabyan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Psalm_151" title="Psalm 151">Psalm 151</a> at the end of the Psalter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wells1911_153-2"><a href="#cite_note-Wells1911-153">[n]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FUP1970_151-2"><a href="#cite_note-FUP1970-151">[l]</a></sup> The three books of Meqabyan are not to be confused with the books of Maccabees. The order of the books is somewhat different in that the Ethiopian Old Testament follows the Septuagint order for the Minor Prophets rather than the Jewish order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethiopian_201-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ethiopian-201">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Influence">Influence</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Role_of_Christianity_in_civilization" title="Role of Christianity in civilization">Role of Christianity in civilization</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Christian_thought_on_persecution_and_tolerance" title="History of Christian thought on persecution and tolerance">History of Christian thought on persecution and tolerance</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Bible_and_violence" title="The Bible and violence">The Bible and violence</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Women_in_the_Bible" title="Women in the Bible">Women in the  Bible</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Category:Works_based_on_the_Bible" title="Category:Works based on the Bible">Category:Works based on the Bible</a></div>
<p>With a literary tradition spanning two millennia, the Bible is one of the most influential works ever written. From practices of personal hygiene to philosophy and ethics, the Bible has directly and indirectly influenced politics and law, war and peace, sexual morals, marriage and family life, letters and learning, the arts, economics, social justice, medical care and more.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERiches2000ch._1_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERiches2000ch._1-202">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Bible is one of the world's most published books, with estimated total sales of over five billion copies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WSJ_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ-203">[172]</a></sup> As such, the Bible has had a profound influence, especially in the <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western world</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[174]</a></sup> where the <a href="/wiki/Gutenberg_Bible" title="Gutenberg Bible">Gutenberg Bible</a> was the first book printed in Europe using <a href="/wiki/Movable_type" title="Movable type">movable type</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERiches2000chs._1_and_4_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERiches2000chs._1_and_4-206">[175]</a></sup> It has contributed to the formation of <a href="/wiki/Western_law" title="Western law">Western law</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_art" title="Western art">art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_literature" title="Western literature">literature</a>, and education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism">Criticism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/The_Bible_and_slavery" title="The Bible and slavery">The Bible and slavery</a></div>
<p>Critics view certain biblical texts to be morally problematic. The Bible neither calls for nor condemns <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">slavery</a> outright, but there are verses that address dealing with it, and these verses have been used to support it. Some have written that <a href="/wiki/Supersessionism" title="Supersessionism">supersessionism</a> begins in the book of Hebrews where others locate its beginnings in the culture of the fourth century Roman empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Michael_J._Vlach_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-Michael_J._Vlach-208">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 1">: 1 </span></sup> The Bible has been used to support the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Death_penalty" title="Death penalty">death penalty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patriarchy" title="Patriarchy">patriarchy</a>, sexual intolerance, the <a href="/wiki/Violence" title="Violence">violence</a> of <a href="/wiki/Total_war" title="Total war">Total war</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Colonialism" title="Colonialism">colonialism</a>.
</p><p>In the Christian Bible, the violence of war is addressed four ways: <a href="/wiki/Pacifism" title="Pacifism">pacifism</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-resistance" title="Non-resistance">non-resistance</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Just_war" title="Just war">just war</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Preventive_war" title="Preventive war">preventive war</a> which is sometimes called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crusade" title="Crusade">crusade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Robert_G._Clouse_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-Robert_G._Clouse-209">[178]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 13–37">: 13–37 </span></sup> In the Hebrew Bible, there is <i>just war</i> and <i>preventive war</i> which includes the Amalekites, Canaanites, Moabites, and the record in Exodus, Deuteronomy, Joshua, and both books of Kings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A.G.Hunter_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-A.G.Hunter-210">[179]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_J._Collins" title="John J. Collins">John J. Collins</a> writes that people throughout history have used these biblical texts to justify violence against their enemies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[180]</a></sup> Anthropologist <a href="/wiki/Leonard_Glick" title="Leonard Glick">Leonard B. Glick</a> offers the modern example of  <a href="/wiki/Jewish_fundamentalism" title="Jewish fundamentalism">Jewish fundamentalists</a> in Israel, such as <a href="/wiki/Shlomo_Aviner" title="Shlomo Aviner">Shlomo Aviner</a> a prominent theorist of the Gush Emunim movement, who considers the <a href="/wiki/Palestinians" title="Palestinians">Palestinians</a> to be like biblical Canaanites, and therefore suggests that Israel "must be prepared to destroy" the Palestinians if the Palestinians do not leave the land.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Nur_Masalha" title="Nur Masalha">Nur Masalha</a> argues that <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a> is inherent in these commandments, and that they have served as inspirational examples of divine support for slaughtering national opponents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[182]</a></sup> The "applicability of the term [genocide] to earlier periods of <a href="/wiki/Human_history" title="Human history">history</a>" is questioned by sociologists Frank Robert Chalk and Kurt Jonassohn.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Frank_Robert_Chalk_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-Frank_Robert_Chalk-214">[183]</a></sup> Since most societies of the past endured and practiced genocide, it was accepted at that time as "being in the nature of life" because of the "coarseness and brutality" of life; the moral condemnation associated with terms like genocide are products of modern morality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Frank_Robert_Chalk_214-1"><a href="#cite_note-Frank_Robert_Chalk-214">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 27">: 27 </span></sup> The definition of what constitutes violence has broadened considerably over time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Matthew_Lynch_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-Matthew_Lynch-215">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 1–2">: 1–2 </span></sup> The Bible reflects how perceptions of violence changed for its authors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Matthew_Lynch_215-1"><a href="#cite_note-Matthew_Lynch-215">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 261">: 261 </span></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Phyllis_Trible" title="Phyllis Trible">Phyllis Trible</a>, in her now famous work <i>Texts of Terror,</i> tells four Bible stories of suffering in ancient Israel where women are the victims. Tribble describes the Bible as "a mirror" that reflects humans, and human life, in all its "holiness and horror".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>John Riches, professor of divinity and biblical criticism at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Glasgow" title="University of Glasgow">University of Glasgow</a>, provides the following view of the diverse historical influences of the Bible:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>It has inspired some of the great monuments of human thought, literature, and art; it has equally fuelled some of the worst excesses of human savagery, self-interest, and narrow-mindedness. It has inspired men and women to acts of great service and courage, to fight for liberation and human development; and it has provided the ideological fuel for societies which have enslaved their fellow human beings and reduced them to abject poverty. ... It has, perhaps above all, provided a source of religious and moral norms which have enabled communities to hold together, to care for, and to protect one another; yet precisely this strong sense of belonging has in turn fuelled ethnic, racial, and international tension and conflict. It has, that is to say, been the source of great truth, goodness, and beauty at the same time as it has inspired lies, wickedness, and ugliness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERiches2000134_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERiches2000134-217">[186]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics_and_law">Politics and law</span></h3>
<p>The Bible has been used to support and oppose political power. It has inspired revolution and "a reversal of power" because God is so often portrayed as choosing what is "weak and humble (the stammering Moses, the infant Samuel, Saul from an insignificant family, David confronting Goliath, etc.) to confound the mighty".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[188]</a></sup> Biblical texts have been the catalyst for political concepts like <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religious_toleration" title="Religious toleration">religious toleration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">religious freedom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scribner_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scribner-220">[189]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 3">: 3 </span></sup> These have, in turn, inspired movements ranging from <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism" title="Abolitionism">abolitionism</a> in the 18th and 19th century, to the <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights_movement" title="Civil rights movement">civil rights movement</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Apartheid_Movement" title="Anti-Apartheid Movement">Anti-Apartheid Movement</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Liberation_theology" title="Liberation theology">liberation theology</a> in Latin America. The Bible has, in turn, been the source of many peace movements around the world and efforts at reconciliation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>The roots of many modern laws can be found in the Bible's teachings on due process, fairness in criminal procedures, and equity in the application of the law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[191]</a></sup> Judges are told not to accept bribes (Deuteronomy 16:19), are required to be impartial to native and stranger alike (Leviticus 24:22; Deuteronomy 27:19), to the needy and the powerful alike (Leviticus 19:15), and to rich and poor alike (Deuteronomy 1:16, 17; Exodus 23:2–6). The right to a fair trial, and fair punishment, are also found in the Bible (Deuteronomy 19:15; Exodus 21:23–25). Those most vulnerable in a patriarchal society – children, women, and strangers – are singled out in the Bible for special protection (Psalm 72:2, 4).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christopher_Marshall_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-Christopher_Marshall-223">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 47–48">: 47–48 </span></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_responsibility">Social responsibility</span></h3>
<p>The philosophical foundation of human rights is in the Bible's teachings of natural law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Levent_Gönenç_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-Levent_Gönenç-224">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-David_Kim_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-David_Kim-225">[194]</a></sup> The prophets of the Hebrew Bible repeatedly admonish the people to practice justice, charity, and social responsibility. H. A. Lockton writes that "The Poverty and Justice Bible (The Bible Society (UK), 2008) claims there are more than 2000 verses in the Bible dealing with the justice issues of rich-poor relations, exploitation and oppression".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[195]</a></sup>  Judaism practiced charity and healing the sick but tended to limit these practices to their own people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bullough_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bullough-227">[196]</a></sup> For Christians, the Old Testament statements are enhanced by multiple verses such as Matthew 10:8, Luke 10:9 and 9:2, and Acts 5:16 that say "heal the sick". Authors Vern and Bonnie Bullough write in <i>The care of the sick: the emergence of modern nursing,</i> that this is seen as an aspect of following Jesus' example, since so much of his public ministry focused on healing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bullough_227-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bullough-227">[196]</a></sup> In the process of following this command, monasticism in the third century transformed health care.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrislip20053_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrislip20053-228">[197]</a></sup> This produced the first hospital for the poor in Caesarea in the fourth century. The monastic <a href="/wiki/Health_system" title="Health system">health care system</a> was innovative in its methods, allowing the sick to remain within the <a href="/wiki/Monastery" title="Monastery">monastery</a> as a special class afforded special benefits; it <a href="/wiki/Social_stigma" title="Social stigma">destigmatized</a> illness, legitimized the <a href="/wiki/Deviance_(sociology)" title="Deviance (sociology)">deviance</a> from the norm that sickness includes, and formed the basis for future modern concepts of public health care.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrislip200568–69,_99_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrislip200568–69,_99-229">[198]</a></sup> The biblical practices of feeding and clothing the poor, visiting prisoners, supporting widows and orphan children have had sweeping impact.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Charles_Schmidt_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-Charles_Schmidt-230">[199]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Establishments_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-Establishments-231">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Teasdale2014_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-Teasdale2014-232">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Bible's emphasis on learning has had formidable influence on believers and western society. For centuries after the fall of the western Roman Empire, all schools in Europe were Bible-based church schools, and outside of monastic settlements, almost no one had the ability to read or write. These schools eventually led to the West's first universities (created by the church) in the Middle Ages which have spread around the world in the modern day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-233">[202]</a></sup> Protestant Reformers wanted all members of the church to be able to read the Bible, so compulsory education for both boys and girls was introduced. Translations of the Bible into local vernacular languages have supported the development of national literatures and the invention of alphabets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESannehMcClymond2016279_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESannehMcClymond2016279-234">[203]</a></sup>
</p><p>Biblical teachings on sexual morality changed the Roman empire, the millennium that followed, and have continued to influence society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarper201314–18_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarper201314–18-235">[204]</a></sup> Rome's concept of sexual morality was centered on social and political status, power, and <a href="/wiki/Social_reproduction" title="Social reproduction">social reproduction</a> (the transmission of social inequality to the next generation). The biblical standard was a "radical notion of individual freedom centered around a libertarian paradigm of complete sexual agency".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rebecca_Langlands_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rebecca_Langlands-236">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 10, 38">: 10, 38 </span></sup> Classicist Kyle Harper describes the change biblical teaching evoked as "a revolution in the rules of behavior, but also in the very image of the human being".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 14–18">: 14–18 </span></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Regnault,_Henri,_Salom%C3%A9.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="854" data-file-width="534" decoding="async" height="352" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Regnault%2C_Henri%2C_Salom%C3%A9.jpg/220px-Regnault%2C_Henri%2C_Salom%C3%A9.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Regnault%2C_Henri%2C_Salom%C3%A9.jpg/330px-Regnault%2C_Henri%2C_Salom%C3%A9.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Regnault%2C_Henri%2C_Salom%C3%A9.jpg/440px-Regnault%2C_Henri%2C_Salom%C3%A9.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Regnault,_Henri,_Salom%C3%A9.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Salom%C3%A9_(Henri_Regnault)" title="Salomé (Henri Regnault)">Salomé</a></i>, by <a href="/wiki/Henri_Regnault" title="Henri Regnault">Henri Regnault</a> (1870).</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_the_arts">Literature and the arts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Films_based_on_the_Bible" title="Films based on the Bible">Films based on the Bible</a>, <a href="/wiki/Category:Operas_based_on_the_Bible" title="Category:Operas based on the Bible">Category:Operas based on the Bible</a>, <a href="/wiki/Category:Books_based_on_the_Bible" title="Category:Books based on the Bible">Category:Books based on the Bible</a>, <a href="/wiki/Category:Plays_based_on_the_Bible" title="Category:Plays based on the Bible">Category:Plays based on the Bible</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Category:Music_based_on_the_Bible" title="Category:Music based on the Bible">Category:Music based on the Bible</a></div>
<p>The Bible has directly and indirectly influenced literature: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St_Augustine" title="St Augustine">St Augustine</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Confessions_(St._Augustine)" title="Confessions (St. Augustine)">Confessions</a> is widely considered the first autobiography in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Literature" title="Western Literature">Western Literature</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wilken_2003_291_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wilken_2003_291-238">[207]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Summa_Theologica" title="Summa Theologica">Summa Theologica</a>, written 1265–1274, is "one of the classics of the history of philosophy and one of the most influential works of Western literature."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[208]</a></sup> These both influenced the writings of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dante" title="Dante">Dante</a>'s epic poetry and his <i><a href="/wiki/Divine_Comedy" title="Divine Comedy">Divine Comedy</a></i>, and in turn, Dante's creation and sacramental theology has contributed to influencing writers such as <a href="/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien" title="J. R. R. Tolkien">J. R. R. Tolkien</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[209]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many masterpieces of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_art" title="Western art">Western art</a> were inspired by biblical themes: from Michelangelo's <i><a href="/wiki/David_(Michelangelo)" title="David (Michelangelo)">David</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Piet%C3%A0" title="Pietà">Pietà</a></i> sculptures, to Leonardo da Vinci's <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Last_Supper_(Leonardo_da_Vinci)" title="The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)">Last Supper</a></i> and Raphael's various <i>Madonna</i> paintings. There are hundreds of examples. Eve, the temptress who disobeys God's commandment, is probably the most widely portrayed figure in art.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mati_Meyer_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mati_Meyer-242">[211]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Renaissance" title="The Renaissance">The Renaissance</a> preferred the sensuous female nude, while the "femme fatale" Delilah from the nineteenth century onward demonstrates how the Bible and art both shape and reflect views of women.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[212]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Diane_Apostolos-Cappadona_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-Diane_Apostolos-Cappadona-244">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Bible has many rituals of purification which speak of clean and unclean in both literal and metaphorical terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Warsh_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-Warsh-245">[214]</a></sup> The biblical toilet etiquette encourages washing after all instances of defecation, hence the invention of the bidet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[216]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Interpretation_and_inspiration">Interpretation and inspiration</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Biblical_inspiration" title="Biblical inspiration">Biblical inspiration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biblical_literalism" title="Biblical literalism">Biblical literalism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biblical_infallibility" title="Biblical infallibility">Biblical infallibility</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Biblical_inerrancy" title="Biblical inerrancy">Biblical inerrancy</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Islamic_view_of_the_Bible" title="Islamic view of the Bible">Islamic view of the Bible</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Altar_and_bible_st_Johns_Lutheran.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Altar_and_bible_st_Johns_Lutheran.jpg/220px-Altar_and_bible_st_Johns_Lutheran.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Altar_and_bible_st_Johns_Lutheran.jpg/330px-Altar_and_bible_st_Johns_Lutheran.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Altar_and_bible_st_Johns_Lutheran.jpg/440px-Altar_and_bible_st_Johns_Lutheran.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Altar_and_bible_st_Johns_Lutheran.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Bible is placed centrally on a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lutheran" title="Lutheran">Lutheran</a> altar, highlighting its importance</div></div></div>
<p>Biblical texts have always required interpretation, and this has given rise to multiple views and approaches according to the interplay between various religions and the book.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton20193,_14_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton20193,_14-248">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>The primary source of Jewish commentary and interpretation of the Hebrew Bible is the <a href="/wiki/Talmud" title="Talmud">Talmud</a>. The Talmud, (which means study and learning), is a summary of ancient oral law and commentary on it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteinsaltz20093–4_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteinsaltz20093–4-249">[218]</a></sup> It is the primary source of Jewish Law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteinsaltz20094_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteinsaltz20094-250">[219]</a></sup> Adin Steinsaltz writes that "if the Bible is the cornerstone of Judaism, then the Talmud is the central pillar".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteinsaltz20093_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteinsaltz20093-251">[220]</a></sup> Seen as the backbone of Jewish creativity, it is "a conglomerate of law, legend and philosophy, a blend of unique logic and shrewd pragmatism, of history and science, anecdotes and humor" all aimed toward the purpose of studying biblical Torah.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESteinsaltz20094_250-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESteinsaltz20094-250">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p>Christians often treat the Bible as a single book, and while <a href="/wiki/John_Barton_(theologian)" title="John Barton (theologian)">John Barton</a> says they are "some of the most profound texts humanity has ever produced", liberals and moderates see it as a collection of books that are not perfect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton201913_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton201913-252">[221]</a></sup> Conservative and fundamentalist Christians see the Bible differently and interpret it differently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton20199_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton20199-253">[222]</a></sup> Christianity interprets the Bible differently than Judaism does with Islam providing yet another view.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton2019542_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton2019542-254">[223]</a></sup> How inspiration works and what kind of authority it means the Bible has are different for different traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton20192_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton20192-255">[224]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Second Epistle to Timothy says that "all scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness". (<span class="nourlexpansion nowrap"><a class="external text" href="https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2+Timothy+3%3A16&amp;version=KJV" rel="nofollow">2 Timothy 3:16</a></span>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrudem199449–50_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrudem199449–50-256">[225]</a></sup> Various related but distinguishable views on divine inspiration include:
</p>
<ul><li>the view of the Bible as the inspired word of God: the belief that God, through the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit" title="Holy Spirit">Holy Spirit</a>, intervened and influenced the words, message, and collation of the Bible<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERice196968–88_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERice196968–88-257">[226]</a></sup></li>
<li>the view that the Bible is also <a href="/wiki/Biblical_infallibility" title="Biblical infallibility">infallible</a>, and incapable of error in matters of faith and practice, but not necessarily in historic or scientific matters</li>
<li>the view that the Bible represents the <a href="/wiki/Biblical_inerrancy" title="Biblical inerrancy">inerrant word of God</a>, without error in any aspect, spoken by God and written down in its perfect form by humans</li></ul>
<p>Within these broad beliefs many schools of <a href="/wiki/Hermeneutics" title="Hermeneutics">hermeneutics</a> operate. "Bible scholars claim that discussions about the Bible must be put into its context within church history and then into the context of contemporary culture."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright_149-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wright-149">[138]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christian_fundamentalism" title="Christian fundamentalism">Fundamentalist Christians</a> are associated with the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Biblical_literalism" title="Biblical literalism">biblical literalism</a>, where the Bible is not only inerrant, but the meaning of the text is clear to the average reader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBartkowski1996259–272_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBartkowski1996259–272-258">[227]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jewish antiquity attests to belief in sacred texts,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Josephus_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-Josephus-260">[229]</a></sup> and a similar belief emerges in the earliest of Christian writings. Various texts of the Bible mention divine agency in relation to its writings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[230]</a></sup> In their book <i>A General Introduction to the Bible</i>, <a href="/wiki/Norman_Geisler" title="Norman Geisler">Norman Geisler</a> and William Nix write: "The process of inspiration is a mystery of the providence of God, but the result of this process is a verbal, plenary, inerrant, and authoritative record."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeisler198686_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeisler198686-262">[231]</a></sup> Most evangelical biblical scholars<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZuck199168_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZuck199168-263">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeisler1980294_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeisler1980294-264">[233]</a></sup> associate inspiration with only the original text; for example some American Protestants adhere to the 1978 <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Statement_on_Biblical_Inerrancy" title="Chicago Statement on Biblical Inerrancy">Chicago Statement on Biblical Inerrancy</a> which asserted that inspiration applied only to the <a href="/wiki/Autograph" title="Autograph">autographic</a> text of scripture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[234]</a></sup> Among adherents of biblical literalism, a minority, such as followers of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King-James-Only_Movement" title="King-James-Only Movement">King-James-Only Movement</a>, extend the claim of inerrancy only to a particular version.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[235]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religious_significance">Religious significance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Quran#Significance_in_Islam" title="Quran">Quran § Significance in Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita#Composition_and_significance" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita § Composition and significance</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Torah#Significance_in_Judaism" title="Torah">Torah § Significance in Judaism</a></div><p>
Both Judaism and Christianity see the Bible as religiously and intellectually significant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gellar_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gellar-267">[236]</a></sup> It provides insight into its time and into the composition of the texts, and it represents an important step in the development of thought.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gellar_267-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gellar-267">[236]</a></sup> It is used in communal worship, recited and memorized, provides personal guidance, a basis for counseling, church doctrine, religious culture (teaching, hymns and worship), and ethical standards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gellar_267-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gellar-267">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Banbaji_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-Banbaji-268">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 145">: 145 </span></sup></p><blockquote><p>The Bible is centrally important to both Judaism and Christianity, but not as a holy text out of which entire religious systems can somehow be read. Its contents  illuminate the origins of Christianity and Judaism, and provide spiritual classics on which both faiths can draw; but they do not constrain subsequent generations in the way that a written constitution would. They are simply not that kind of thing. They are a repository of writings, both shaping and shaped by the two religions..."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton20194_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton20194-269">[238]</a></sup></p></blockquote><p> As a result, there are teachings and creeds in Christianity and laws in Judaism that are seen as derived from the Bible which are not directly in the Bible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarton20193_84-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarton20193-84">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>For the Hebrew Bible, canonization is reserved for written texts, while sacralization reaches far back into <a href="/wiki/Oral_tradition" title="Oral tradition">oral tradition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horsley,_Draper,_Foley_&amp;_Kelber_2011_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-Horsley,_Draper,_Foley_&amp;_Kelber_2011-270">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 80">: 80 </span></sup> When sacred stories, such as those that form the narrative base of the first five books of the Bible, were performed, "not a syllable [could] be changed in order to ensure the magical power of the words to 'presentify' the divine".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horsley,_Draper,_Foley_&amp;_Kelber_2011_270-1"><a href="#cite_note-Horsley,_Draper,_Foley_&amp;_Kelber_2011-270">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 80">: 80 </span></sup> Inflexibility protected the texts from a changing world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horsley,_Draper,_Foley_&amp;_Kelber_2011_270-2"><a href="#cite_note-Horsley,_Draper,_Foley_&amp;_Kelber_2011-270">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 80">: 80 </span></sup> When sacred oral texts began the move to written transmission, commentary began being worked in, but once the text was closed by canonization, commentary needed to remain outside. Commentary still had significance. Sacred written texts were thereafter accompanied by commentary, and such commentary was sometimes written and sometimes orally transmitted, as is the case in the Islamic <a href="/wiki/Madrasa" title="Madrasa">Madrasa</a> and the Jewish <a href="/wiki/Yeshiva" title="Yeshiva">Yeshiva</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horsley,_Draper,_Foley_&amp;_Kelber_2011_270-3"><a href="#cite_note-Horsley,_Draper,_Foley_&amp;_Kelber_2011-270">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 81">: 81 </span></sup> Arguing that Torah has had a definitive role in developing Jewish identity from its earliest days, John J. Collins explains that regardless of genetics or land, one could become Jewish by observing the laws in the Torah, and that remains true in the modern day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[240]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Christian religion and its sacred book are connected and influence one another, but the significance of the written text has varied throughout history. <a href="/wiki/David_M._Carr" title="David M. Carr">David M. Carr</a> writes that early Christianity had a 'flexible' view of the written Hebrew tradition and even its own texts. For Christianity, holiness did not reside in the written text or in any particular language, it resided in the Christ it witnessed to.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 279">: 279 </span></sup> Wilfred Cantwell Smith points out that "in the Islamic system, the Quran fulfills a function comparable to the role... played by the person of Jesus Christ, while a closer counterpart to Christian scriptures are the Islamic <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">Hadith</a> 'Traditions'."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smith_71_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-Smith_71-273">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 133">: 133 </span></sup> For centuries the written text had less significance than the will of the church as represented by the Pope, since the church saw the text as having been created by the church. One cause of the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a> was the perceived need to reorient Christianity around its early text as authoritative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 13">: 13 </span></sup> Some <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestant</a> churches still focus on the idea of <i><a href="/wiki/Sola_scriptura" title="Sola scriptura">sola scriptura</a></i>, which sees scripture as the only legitimate religious authority. Some denominations today support the use of the Bible as the only <a href="/wiki/Biblical_infallibility" title="Biblical infallibility">infallible</a> source of Christian teaching. Others, though, advance the concept of <i><a href="/wiki/Prima_scriptura" title="Prima scriptura">prima scriptura</a></i> in contrast, meaning scripture primarily or scripture mainly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WELS_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-WELS-276">[af]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Humphrey2013_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-Humphrey2013-277">[ag]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the twenty-first century, attitudes towards the significance of the Bible continue to differ. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholics" title="Roman Catholics">Roman Catholics</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_Church" title="High Church">High Church</a> <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglicans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Methodism" title="Methodism">Methodists</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> Christians stress the harmony and importance of both the Bible and <a href="/wiki/Sacred_tradition" title="Sacred tradition">sacred tradition</a> in combination. United Methodists see Scripture as the major factor in Christian doctrine, but they also emphasize the importance of tradition, experience, and reason. Lutherans teach that the Bible is the sole source for Christian doctrine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wels.net_275-1"><a href="#cite_note-wels.net-275">[244]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islamic_view_of_the_Bible" title="Islamic view of the Bible">Muslims view the Bible</a> as reflecting the true unfolding <a href="/wiki/Revelation" title="Revelation">revelation</a> from <a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">God</a>; but revelation which had been corrupted or distorted (in Arabic: <i><a href="/wiki/Tahrif" title="Tahrif">tahrif</a></i>), and therefore necessitated correction by giving the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prophets_of_Islam" title="Prophets of Islam">Islamic prophet</a> <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[ah]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Rastafari" title="Rastafari">Rastafari</a> view the Bible as essential to their religion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPrice2009171_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPrice2009171-280">[246]</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Unitarian_Universalism" title="Unitarian Universalism">Unitarian Universalists</a> view it as "one of many important religious texts".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGomes200942_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGomes200942-281">[247]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Versions_and_translations">Versions and translations</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Bible_translations" title="Bible translations">Bible translations</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Bible_translations_by_language" title="List of Bible translations by language">List of Bible translations by language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bible_translations_into_English" title="Bible translations into English">Bible translations into English</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_English_Bible_translations" title="List of English Bible translations">List of English Bible translations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1588_First_Welsh_Bible.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1169" data-file-width="733" decoding="async" height="287" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/1588_First_Welsh_Bible.jpg/180px-1588_First_Welsh_Bible.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/1588_First_Welsh_Bible.jpg/270px-1588_First_Welsh_Bible.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/1588_First_Welsh_Bible.jpg/360px-1588_First_Welsh_Bible.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1588_First_Welsh_Bible.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Title page from the first <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a> translation of the Bible, 1588. <a href="/wiki/William_Morgan_(Bible_translator)" title="William Morgan (Bible translator)">William Morgan</a> (1545–1604)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lutherbibel.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="759" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Lutherbibel.jpg/220px-Lutherbibel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Lutherbibel.jpg/330px-Lutherbibel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Lutherbibel.jpg/440px-Lutherbibel.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lutherbibel.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An early German translation by <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther" title="Martin Luther">Martin Luther</a>. His translation of the text into the <a href="/wiki/Vernacular" title="Vernacular">vernacular</a> was highly influential.</div></div></div>
<p>The original texts of the Tanakh were almost entirely written in Hebrew with about one percent in Aramaic. The earliest translation of any Bible text is the Septuagint which translated the Hebrew into Greek.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202175_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202175-34">[33]</a></sup> As the first translation of any biblical literature, the translation that became the Septuagint was an unparalleled event in the ancient world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarcos200018_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcos200018-282">[248]</a></sup> This translation was made possible by a common Mediterranean culture where Semitism had been foundational to Greek culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarcos200019_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcos200019-283">[249]</a></sup> In the Talmud, Greek is the only language officially allowed for translation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarcos200021_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcos200021-126">[118]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Targum_Onkelos" title="Targum Onkelos">Targum Onkelos</a> is the Aramaic translation of the Hebrew Bible believed to have been written in the second century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202175_34-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202175-34">[33]</a></sup> These texts attracted the work of various scholars, but a standardized text was not available before the 9th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202175_34-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202175-34">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were different ancient versions of the Tanakh in Hebrew. These were copied and edited in three different locations producing slightly varying results. Masoretic scholars in Tiberias in ancient Palestine copied the ancient texts in Tiberian Hebrew. A copy was recovered from the "Cave of Elijah" (the synagogue of Aleppo in the Judean desert) and is therefore referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Aleppo_Codex" title="Aleppo Codex">Aleppo Codex</a> which dates to around 920. This codex, which is over a thousand years old, was originally the oldest codex of the complete Tiberian Hebrew Bible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoshen-Gottstein1979145_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoshen-Gottstein1979145-284">[250]</a></sup> Babylonian masoretes had also copied the early texts, and the Tiberian and Babylonian were later combined, using the Aleppo Codex and additional writings, to form the <a href="/wiki/Aaron_ben_Moses_ben_Asher" title="Aaron ben Moses ben Asher">Ben-Asher</a> <a href="/wiki/Masoretic_Text" title="Masoretic Text">masoretic</a> tradition which is the standardized Hebrew Bible of today. The Aleppo Codex is no longer the oldest complete manuscript because, during riots in 1947, the Aleppo Codex was removed from its location, and about 40% of it was subsequently lost. It must now rely on additional manuscripts, and as a result, the Aleppo Codex contains the most comprehensive collection of variant readings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint201387_35-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint201387-35">[34]</a></sup> The oldest complete version of the Masoretic tradition is the Leningrad Codex from 1008. It is the source for all modern Jewish and Christian translations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202175_34-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202175-34">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoshen-Gottstein1979145_284-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoshen-Gottstein1979145-284">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>Levidas writes that, "The Koine Greek New Testament is a non-translated work; most scholars agree on this – despite disagreement on the possibility that some passages may have appeared initially in Aramaic... It is written in the Koine Greek of the first century [CE]".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202163_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202163-285">[251]</a></sup> Early Christians translated the New Testament into <a href="/wiki/Syriac_versions_of_the_Bible" title="Syriac versions of the Bible">Old Syriac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coptic_language" title="Coptic language">Coptic</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ge%27ez_language" title="Ge'ez language">Ethiopic</a>, and Latin, among other languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202129_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202129-50">[48]</a></sup>  The earliest Latin translation was the <a href="/wiki/Old_Latin" title="Old Latin">Old Latin</a> text, or <i><a href="/wiki/Vetus_Latina" title="Vetus Latina">Vetus Latina</a></i>, which, from internal evidence, seems to have been made by several authors over a period of time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202176_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202176-286">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKrauss2017105–106_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKrauss2017105–106-287">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pope_Damasus_I" title="Pope Damasus I">Pope Damasus I</a> (366–383) commissioned <a href="/wiki/Jerome" title="Jerome">Jerome</a> to produce a reliable and consistent text by translating the original Greek and Hebrew texts into Latin. This translation became known as the <a href="/wiki/Vulgate" title="Vulgate">Latin Vulgate Bible</a>, in the 4th century CE (although Jerome expressed in his prologues to most deuterocanonical books that they were non-canonical).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKelly2000[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidUivDgM0WywoCpgPA55vonepage_55]_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKelly2000[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidUivDgM0WywoCpgPA55vonepage_55]-288">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[255]</a></sup> In 1546, at the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a>, Jerome's Vulgate translation was declared by the Roman Catholic Church to be the only authentic and official Bible in the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[256]</a></sup> The Greek-speaking East continued to use the Septuagint translations of the Old Testament, and they had no need to translate the Greek New Testament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202176_286-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202176-286">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKrauss2017105–106_287-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKrauss2017105–106-287">[253]</a></sup> This contributed to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East-West_Schism" title="East-West Schism">East-West Schism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201740Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr20103–5Bandstra20097–8,_480–481Gravett_et_al.2008xvHarrisPlatzner20083–4,_28,_371Riches2000ch._3_54-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201740Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr20103–5Bandstra20097–8,_480–481Gravett_et_al.2008xvHarrisPlatzner20083–4,_28,_371Riches2000ch._3-54">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many ancient translations coincide with the invention of the alphabet and the beginning of vernacular literature in those languages. According to British Academy professor N. Fernández Marcos, these early translations represent "pioneer works of enormous linguistic interest, as they represent the oldest documents we have for the study of these languages and literature".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMarcos2000322–323,_346–347_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMarcos2000322–323,_346–347-291">[257]</a></sup>
</p><p>Translations to English can be traced to the seventh century, <a href="/wiki/Alfred_the_Great" title="Alfred the Great">Alfred the Great</a> in the 9th century, the <i><a href="/wiki/Toledo_School_of_Translators" title="Toledo School of Translators">Toledo School of Translators</a></i> in the 12th and 13th century, <a href="/wiki/Roger_Bacon" title="Roger Bacon">Roger Bacon</a> (1220–1292), an English Franciscan monk of the 13th century, and multiple writers of the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202130–31_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202130–31-292">[258]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Wycliffe%27s_Bible" title="Wycliffe's Bible">Wycliffite Bible</a>, which is "one of the most significant in the development of a written standard", dates from the late Middle English period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202141_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202141-293">[259]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tyndale_Bible" title="Tyndale Bible">William Tyndale's translation</a> of 1525 is seen by several scholars as having influenced the form of English Christian discourse as well as impacting the development of the English language itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202141–42_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202141–42-294">[260]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther" title="Martin Luther">Martin Luther</a> translated the New Testament into German in 1522, and both Testaments with Apocrypha in 1534, thereby contributing to the multiple wars of the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Age of Reformation and Counter-Reformation</a>. Important biblical translations of this period include the Polish <i>Jakub Wujek Bible</i> (Biblia Jakuba Wujka) from 1535, and the English King James/Authorized Version (1604–1611).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavidas202131_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavidas202131-295">[261]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/King_James_Version" title="King James Version">King James Version</a> was the most widespread English Bible of all time, but it has largely been superseded by modern translations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201740,_46,_49,_58–59Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr20103–5Bandstra20097–8,_480–481Gravett_et_al.2008xv,_49HarrisPlatzner20083–4,_28,_31–32,_371Riches2000ch._3_55-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201740,_46,_49,_58–59Hayes2012ch._1Brown2010Intro.Carr20103–5Bandstra20097–8,_480–481Gravett_et_al.2008xv,_49HarrisPlatzner20083–4,_28,_31–32,_371Riches2000ch._3-55">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nearly all modern English translations of the Old Testament are based on a single manuscript, the <a href="/wiki/Leningrad_Codex" title="Leningrad Codex">Leningrad Codex</a>, copied in 1008 or 1009. It is a complete example of the Masoretic Text, and its published edition is used by the majority of scholars. The <a href="/wiki/Aleppo_Codex" title="Aleppo Codex">Aleppo Codex</a> is the basis of the Hebrew University Bible Project in Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint201387_35-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVanderKamFlint201387-35">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the Reformation era, <a href="/wiki/Bible_translations" title="Bible translations">Bible translations</a> have been made into the common vernacular of many languages. The Bible continues to be translated to new languages, largely by Christian organizations such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wycliffe_Bible_Translators" title="Wycliffe Bible Translators">Wycliffe Bible Translators</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Tribes_Mission" title="New Tribes Mission">New Tribes Mission</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bible_society" title="Bible society">Bible societies</a>. Lammin Sanneh writes that tracing the impact on the local cultures of translating the Bible into local vernacular language shows it has produced "the movements of indigenization and cultural liberation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESannehMcClymond2016265_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESannehMcClymond2016265-296">[262]</a></sup> "The translated scripture ... has become the benchmark of awakening and renewal".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESannehMcClymond2016279_234-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESannehMcClymond2016279-234">[203]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
