<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Archaeological_and_historical_research">Archaeological and historical research</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JRSLM_300116_Tel_Dan_Stele_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1408" data-file-width="1455" decoding="async" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/JRSLM_300116_Tel_Dan_Stele_01.jpg/220px-JRSLM_300116_Tel_Dan_Stele_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/JRSLM_300116_Tel_Dan_Stele_01.jpg/330px-JRSLM_300116_Tel_Dan_Stele_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/JRSLM_300116_Tel_Dan_Stele_01.jpg/440px-JRSLM_300116_Tel_Dan_Stele_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JRSLM_300116_Tel_Dan_Stele_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tel_Dan_Stele" title="Tel Dan Stele">Tel Dan Stele</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israel_Museum" title="Israel Museum">Israel Museum</a>. Highlighted in white: the sequence <i><a href="/wiki/Bet_(letter)" title="Bet (letter)">B</a> <a href="/wiki/Yodh" title="Yodh">Y</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tav_(letter)" title="Tav (letter)">T</a> <a href="/wiki/Dalet" title="Dalet">D</a> <a href="/wiki/Waw_(letter)" title="Waw (letter)">W</a> <a href="/wiki/Dalet" title="Dalet">D</a></i>.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Biblical_archaeology_school" title="Biblical archaeology school">Biblical archaeology school</a>, <a href="/wiki/Historicity_of_the_Bible" title="Historicity of the Bible">Historicity of the Bible</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religiously_motivated_pseudoarchaeology" title="Religiously motivated pseudoarchaeology">Religiously motivated pseudoarchaeology</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Dating_the_Bible" title="Dating the Bible">Dating the Bible</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Biblical_archaeology" title="Biblical archaeology">Biblical archaeology</a> is a subsection of <a href="/wiki/Archaeology" title="Archaeology">archaeology</a> that relates to and sheds light upon the Hebrew scriptures and the New Testament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECaraherPettegrew201919_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECaraherPettegrew201919-298">[264]</a></sup> It is used to help determine the lifestyle and practices of people living in biblical times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECaraherPettegrew201911_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECaraherPettegrew201911-299">[265]</a></sup> There are a wide range of interpretations in the field of biblical archaeology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMazar200385–87_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMazar200385–87-300">[266]</a></sup> One broad division includes <a href="/wiki/Biblical_maximalism" title="Biblical maximalism">biblical maximalism</a> which generally takes the view that most of the Old Testament or the Hebrew Bible is based on history although it is presented through the religious viewpoint of its time. According to historian <a href="/wiki/Lester_L._Grabbe" title="Lester L. Grabbe">Lester L. Grabbe</a>, there are few, if any, maximalists in mainstream scholarship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrabbe201736_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrabbe201736-301">[267]</a></sup> It is considered to be the extreme opposite of <a href="/wiki/Biblical_minimalism" title="Biblical minimalism">biblical minimalism</a> which considers the Bible to be a purely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Post-exilic" title="Post-exilic">post-exilic</a> (5th century BCE and later) composition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavies200027_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavies200027-302">[268]</a></sup> According to Mary-Joan Leith, professor of religious studies, many minimalists have ignored evidence for the antiquity of the Hebrew language in the Bible, and few take archaeological evidence into consideration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeith20225_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeith20225-303">[269]</a></sup> Most biblical scholars and archaeologists fall somewhere on a spectrum between these two.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeith20224_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeith20224-304">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrabbe201736_301-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrabbe201736-301">[267]</a></sup>
</p><p>The biblical account of events of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exodus_from_Egypt" title="Exodus from Egypt">Exodus from Egypt</a> in the Torah, the migration to the <a href="/wiki/Promised_Land" title="Promised Land">Promised Land</a>, and the period of <a href="/wiki/Biblical_judges" title="Biblical judges">Judges</a> are sources of heated ongoing debate. There is an absence of evidence for the presence of Israel in Egypt from any Egyptian source, historical or archaeological.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoffmeier199953_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoffmeier199953-305">[271]</a></sup> Yet, as William Dever points out, these biblical traditions were written long after the events they describe, and they are based in sources now lost and older oral traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDever20038_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDever20038-306">[272]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Hebrew Bible/Old Testament, ancient non–biblical texts, and archaeology support the <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_captivity" title="Babylonian captivity">Babylonian captivity</a> beginning around 586 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeith20221_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeith20221-307">[273]</a></sup> Excavations in southern Judah show a pattern of destruction consistent with the Neo-Assyrian devastation of Judah at the end of the eighth century BCE and 2 Kings 18:13.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeith20226_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeith20226-308">[274]</a></sup> In 1993, at Tel Dan, archaeologist Avraham Biran unearthed a fragmentary Aramaic inscription, the <a href="/wiki/Tel_Dan_stele" title="Tel Dan stele">Tel Dan stele</a>, dated to the late ninth or early eighth century that mentions a "king of Israel" as well as a "house of David" (bet David). This shows David could not be a late sixth-century invention, and implies that Judah's kings traced their lineage back to someone named David.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeith20222_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeith20222-309">[275]</a></sup> However, there is no current archaeological evidence for the existence of Kings David and Solomon or the First Temple as far back as the tenth century BCE where the Bible places them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeith20222–3_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeith20222–3-310">[276]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the nineteenth and early twentieth century, surveys demonstrated that Acts of the Apostles (Acts) scholarship was divided into two traditions, "a conservative (largely British) tradition which had great confidence in the historicity of Acts and a less conservative (largely German) tradition which had very little confidence in the historicity of Acts". Subsequent surveys show that little has changed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhillips2006365_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhillips2006365-311">[277]</a></sup> Author Thomas E. Phillips writes that "In this two-century-long debate over the historicity of Acts and its underlying traditions, only one assumption seemed to be shared by all: Acts was intended to be read as history".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhillips2006366_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhillips2006366-312">[278]</a></sup> This too is now being debated by scholars as: what genre does Acts actually belong to?<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhillips2006366_312-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhillips2006366-312">[278]</a></sup> There is a growing consensus, however, that the question of genre is unsolvable and would not, in any case, solve the issue of historicity: "Is Acts history or fiction? In the eyes of most scholars, it is history – but not the kind of history that precludes fiction." says Phillips.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhillips2006385_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhillips2006385-313">[279]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biblical_criticism">Biblical criticism</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Biblical_studies" title="Biblical studies">Biblical studies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biblical_criticism" title="Biblical criticism">Biblical criticism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Historical_criticism" title="Historical criticism">Historical criticism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Textual_criticism" title="Textual criticism">Textual criticism</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Biblical_authority" title="Biblical authority">Biblical authority</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Facult%C3%A9_de_M%C3%A9decine_Purpan_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Facult%C3%A9_de_M%C3%A9decine_Purpan_01.jpg/220px-Facult%C3%A9_de_M%C3%A9decine_Purpan_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Facult%C3%A9_de_M%C3%A9decine_Purpan_01.jpg/330px-Facult%C3%A9_de_M%C3%A9decine_Purpan_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Facult%C3%A9_de_M%C3%A9decine_Purpan_01.jpg/440px-Facult%C3%A9_de_M%C3%A9decine_Purpan_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Facult%C3%A9_de_M%C3%A9decine_Purpan_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Jean_Astruc" title="Jean Astruc">Jean Astruc</a>, often called the "father of biblical criticism", at <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Centre_hospitalier_universitaire_de_Toulouse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Centre hospitalier universitaire de Toulouse (page does not exist)">Centre hospitalier universitaire de Toulouse</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;"> [<a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_hospitalier_universitaire_de_Toulouse" title="fr:Centre hospitalier universitaire de Toulouse">fr</a>]</span></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Biblical_criticism" title="Biblical criticism">Biblical criticism</a> refers to the analytical investigation of the Bible as a text, and addresses questions such as history, authorship, dates of composition, and authorial intention. It is not the same as <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_the_Bible" title="Criticism of the Bible">criticism of the Bible</a>, which is an assertion against the Bible being a source of information or ethical guidance, nor is it criticism of possible <a href="/wiki/Translation" title="Translation">translation</a> errors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[280]</a></sup>
</p><p>Biblical criticism made study of the Bible secularized, scholarly and more democratic, while it also permanently altered the way people understood the Bible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESoulenSoulen200122_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESoulenSoulen200122-315">[281]</a></sup> The Bible is no longer thought of solely as a religious artifact, and its interpretation is no longer restricted to the community of believers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFishbane1992129_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFishbane1992129-316">[282]</a></sup> Michael Fishbane writes, "There are those who regard the desacralization of the Bible as the fortunate condition for" the development of the modern world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFishbane1992121_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFishbane1992121-317">[283]</a></sup> For many, biblical criticism "released a host of threats" to the Christian faith. For others biblical criticism "proved to be a failure, due principally to the assumption that diachronic, linear research could master any and all of the questions and problems attendant on interpretation".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarrisville2014vii_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarrisville2014vii-318">[284]</a></sup> Still others believed that biblical criticism, "shorn of its unwarranted arrogance," could be a reliable source of interpretation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarrisville2014vii_318-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarrisville2014vii-318">[284]</a></sup> Michael Fishbane compares biblical criticism to <a href="/wiki/Job_(biblical_figure)" title="Job (biblical figure)">Job</a>, a prophet who destroyed "self-serving visions for the sake of a more honest crossing from the divine <i>textus</i> to the human one".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFishbane1992129_316-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFishbane1992129-316">[282]</a></sup> Or as Rogerson says: biblical criticism has been liberating for those who want their faith "intelligently grounded and intellectually honest".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERogerson2000[httpsarchiveorgdetailsoxfordcompaniont00hastpage298_298]_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERogerson2000[httpsarchiveorgdetailsoxfordcompaniont00hastpage298_298]-319">[285]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Bible_museums">Bible museums</span></h2>
<ul><li>The Dunham Bible Museum is located in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Houston_Baptist_University" title="Houston Baptist University">Houston Baptist University</a>,<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Houston,_Texas" title="Houston, Texas">Houston</a>, Texas. It is known for its collection of rare Bibles from around the world and for having many different Bibles of various languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[286]</a></sup></li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_the_Bible" title="Museum of the Bible">Museum of the Bible</a> opened in <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> in November 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[287]</a></sup> The museum states that its intent is to "share the historical relevance and significance of the sacred scriptures in a nonsectarian way", but this has been questioned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[289]</a></sup></li>
<li>The Bible Museum in <a href="/wiki/St_Arnaud,_Victoria" title="St Arnaud, Victoria">St Arnaud, Victoria</a>, Australia opened in 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[290]</a></sup> As of 2020, it is closed for relocation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[291]</a></sup></li>
<li>There is a Bible Museum at <i><a href="/wiki/Passion_Play#United_States" title="Passion Play">The Great Passion Play</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Eureka_Springs,_Arkansas" title="Eureka Springs, Arkansas">Eureka Springs, Arkansas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWright2008[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidonBZhX0H9YkCqthegreatpassionplayarkansaseurekaspringspgPA327_327]_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWright2008[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidonBZhX0H9YkCqthegreatpassionplayarkansaseurekaspringspgPA327_327]-327">[293]</a></sup></li>
<li>The Bible Museum on the Square in <a href="/wiki/Collierville,_Tennessee" title="Collierville, Tennessee">Collierville, Tennessee</a> opened in 1997.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[294]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[295]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Biedenharn_Museum_and_Gardens" title="Biedenharn Museum and Gardens">Biedenharn Museum and Gardens</a> in <a href="/wiki/Monroe,_Louisiana" title="Monroe, Louisiana">Monroe, Louisiana</a> includes a Bible Museum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFonseca1996[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidDGfg8QoWY_ECq22BibleMuseum22BiedenharnpgPA249_249]_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFonseca1996[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidDGfg8QoWY_ECq22BibleMuseum22BiedenharnpgPA249_249]-330">[296]</a></sup></li></ul>

</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Illustrations">Illustrations</span></h2>
<p>The grandest medieval Bibles were <a href="/wiki/Illuminated_manuscript" title="Illuminated manuscript">illuminated manuscripts</a> in which the text is supplemented by the addition of decoration, such as decorated <a href="/wiki/Initial" title="Initial">initials</a>, borders (<a href="/wiki/Marginalia" title="Marginalia">marginalia</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Miniature_(illuminated_manuscript)" title="Miniature (illuminated manuscript)">miniature illustrations</a>. Up to the 12th century, most manuscripts were produced in monasteries in order to add to the library or after receiving a <a href="/wiki/Commission_(art)" title="Commission (art)">commission</a> from a wealthy patron. Larger monasteries often contained separate areas for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monks" title="Monks">monks</a> who specialized in the production of manuscripts called a <a href="/wiki/Scriptorium" title="Scriptorium">scriptorium</a>, where "separate little rooms were assigned to book copying; they were situated in such a way that each scribe had to himself a window open to the cloister walk."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiringer2013[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidBOjCAgAAQBAJpgPA208vonepage_208]_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiringer2013[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidBOjCAgAAQBAJpgPA208vonepage_208]-331">[297]</a></sup> By the 14th century, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cloisters" title="Cloisters">cloisters</a> of monks writing in the scriptorium started to employ laybrothers from the urban scriptoria, especially in Paris, Rome and the Netherlands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDe_Hamel199245_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDe_Hamel199245-332">[298]</a></sup>
Demand for manuscripts grew to an extent that the Monastic libraries were unable to meet with the demand, and began employing secular scribes and illuminators.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDe_Hamel199257_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDe_Hamel199257-333">[299]</a></sup> These individuals often lived close to the monastery and, in certain instances, dressed as monks whenever they entered the monastery, but were allowed to leave at the end of the day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDe_Hamel199265_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDe_Hamel199265-334">[300]</a></sup> A notable example of an illuminated manuscript is the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Kells" title="Book of Kells">Book of Kells</a>, produced circa the year 800 containing the four Gospels of the New Testament together with various prefatory texts and tables.
</p><p>The manuscript was "sent to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rubricator" title="Rubricator">rubricator</a>, who added (in red or other colours) the titles, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Headlines" title="Headlines">headlines</a>, the initials of chapters and sections, the notes and so on; and then – if the book was to be illustrated – it was sent to the illuminator."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiringer2013[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidBOjCAgAAQBAJpgPA213vonepage_213]_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiringer2013[httpsbooksgooglecoukbooksidBOjCAgAAQBAJpgPA213vonepage_213]-335">[301]</a></sup> In the case of manuscripts that were sold commercially, the writing would "undoubtedly have been discussed initially between the patron and the scribe (or the scribe's agent,) but by the time that the written gathering were sent off to the illuminator there was no longer any scope for innovation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDe_Hamel199260_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDe_Hamel199260-336">[302]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerycaption">Bible illustrations</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bible_chartraine_-_BNF_Lat116_f193.jpg" title="Bible from 1150, from Scriptorium de Chartres, Christ with angels"><img alt="Bible from 1150, from Scriptorium de Chartres, Christ with angels" data-file-height="567" data-file-width="510" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Bible_chartraine_-_BNF_Lat116_f193.jpg/180px-Bible_chartraine_-_BNF_Lat116_f193.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Bible_chartraine_-_BNF_Lat116_f193.jpg/270px-Bible_chartraine_-_BNF_Lat116_f193.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Bible_chartraine_-_BNF_Lat116_f193.jpg/360px-Bible_chartraine_-_BNF_Lat116_f193.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-ndq-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ndq_26-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ndq_26-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">"[...] die griechische Bibelübersetzung, die einem innerjüdischen Bedürfnis entsprang [...] [von den] Rabbinen zuerst gerühmt (.) Später jedoch, als manche ungenaue Übertragung des hebräischen Textes in der Septuaginta und Übersetzungsfehler die Grundlage für hellenistische Irrlehren abgaben, lehte man die Septuaginta ab." <a href="#CITEREFHomolkaJacobChorin1999">Homolka, Jacob &amp; Chorin 1999</a>, pp. 43ff, Bd.3</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although a paucity of extant source material makes it impossible to be certain that the earliest Samaritans also rejected the other books of the Tanakh, the 3rd-century church father <a href="/wiki/Origen" title="Origen">Origen</a> confirms that the Samaritans in his day "receive[d] the books of Moses alone." <a href="#CITEREFSchaff1885">Schaff 1885</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/anf04.vi.ix.i.l.html" rel="nofollow">Chapter XLIX</a>(Commentary on John 13:26)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-108"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-108">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Each king is judged either good or bad in black-and-white terms, according to whether or not he "did right" or "did evil" in the sight of the Lord. This evaluation is not reflective of the well-being of the nation, of the king's success or failure in war, or of the moral climate of the times, but rather the state of cultic worship during his reign. Those kings who shun idolatry and enact religious reforms are singled out for praise, and those who encourage pagan practices are denounced." <a href="#CITEREFSavran1987">Savran 1987</a>, p. <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=O4hYlvzWui8C&amp;pg=PA146#v=onepage" rel="nofollow">146</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-109">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The fight against Baal was initiated by the prophets" <a href="#CITEREFKaufmann1956a">Kaufmann 1956a</a>, p. 54</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-110">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The immediate occasion of the rise of the new prophecy was the political and social ruin caused by the wars with Israel's northerly neighbor, Aram, which continued for more than a century. They raged intensely during the reign of Ahab, and did not end until the time of Jeroboam II (784–744). While the nation as a whole was impoverished, a few – apparently of the royal officialdom – grew wealthy as a result of the national calamity. Many of the people were compelled to sell their houses and lands, with the result that a sharp social cleavage arose: on the one hand a mass of propertyless indigents, on the other a small circle of the rich. A series of disasters struck the nation – drought, famine, plagues, death and captivity (Amos 4: 6–11), but the greatest disaster of all was the social disintegration due to the cleavage between the poor masses and the wealthy, dissolute upper class. The decay affected both Judah and Israel ... High minded men were appalled at this development. Was this the people whom YHWH had brought out of Egypt, to whom He had given the land and a law of justice and right? it seemed as if the land was about to be inherited by the rich, who would squander its substance in drunken revelry. it was this dissolution that brought the prophetic denunciations to white heat." <a href="#CITEREFKaufmann1956b">Kaufmann 1956b</a>, pp. 57–58</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-111"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-111">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"What manner of man is the prophet? A student of philosophy who runs from the discourses of the great metaphysicians to the orations of the prophets may feel as if he were going from the realm of the sublime to an area of trivialities. Instead of dealing with the timeless issues of being and becoming, of matter and form, of definitions and demonstrations, he is thrown into orations about widows and orphans, about the corruption of judges and affairs of the market place. Instead of showing us a way through the elegant mansions of the mind, the prophets take us to the slums. The world is a proud place, full of beauty, but the prophets are scandalized, and rave as if the whole world were a slum. They make much ado about paltry things, lavishing excessive language upon trifling subjects. What if somewhere in ancient Palestine poor people have not been treated properly by the rich? .... Indeed, the sorts of crimes and even the amount of delinquency that fill the prophets of Israel with dismay do not go beyond that which we regard as normal, as typical ingredients of social dynamics. To us a single act of injustice – cheating in business, exploitation of the poor – is slight; to the prophets, a disaster. To us an injustice is injurious to the welfare of the people; to the prophets it is a deathblow to existence; to us an episode; to them, a catastrophe, a threat to the world." <a href="#CITEREFHeschel2001">Heschel 2001</a>, pp. 3–4</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-112"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-112">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Samuel is thus a work of national self-criticism. It recognizes that Israel would not have survived, either politically or culturally, without the steadying presence of a dynastic royal house. But it makes both that house and its subjects answerable to firm standards of prophetic justice – not those of cult prophets or professional ecstatics, but of morally upright prophetic leaders in the tradition of Moses, Joshua, Deborah, Gideon, and others ..." <a href="#CITEREFRosenberg1987">Rosenberg 1987</a>, p. <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=O4hYlvzWui8C&amp;pg=PA141#v=onepage" rel="nofollow">141</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-117">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Originally, Ezra and Nehemiah were one book, which were divided in later traditions.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-128"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-128">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> According to the Jewish Encyclopedia: "The translation, which shows at times a peculiar ignorance of Hebrew usage, was evidently made from a codex which differed widely in places from the text crystallized by the Masorah."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JewishEncyclopedia.com_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-JewishEncyclopedia.com-127">[119]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-133"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-133">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Two things, however, rendered the Septuagint unwelcome in the long run to the Jews. Its divergence from the accepted text (afterward called the Masoretic) was too evident; and it therefore could not serve as a basis for theological discussion or for homiletic interpretation. This distrust was accentuated by the fact that it had been adopted as Sacred Scripture by the new faith [Christianity] [...] In course of time it came to be the canonical Greek Bible [...] It became part of the Bible of the Christian Church."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JewishEncyclopedia.com_127-1"><a href="#cite_note-JewishEncyclopedia.com-127">[119]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-134"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-134">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Mishnah Sotah (7:2–4 and 8:1), among many others, discusses the sacredness of Hebrew, as opposed to Aramaic or Greek. This is comparable to the authority claimed for the original Arabic Koran according to Islamic teaching. As a result of this teaching, translations of the Torah into Koine Greek by early Jewish Rabbis have survived as rare fragments only.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FUP1970-151"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FUP1970_151-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FUP1970_151-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FUP1970_151-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Even though they were not placed on the same level as the canonical books, still they were useful for instruction . ... These – and others that total fourteen or fifteen altogether – are the books known as the Apocrypha. <a href="#CITEREFWilliams1970">Williams 1970</a>, p. 141</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Ewert-152"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ewert_152-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"English Bibles were patterned after those of the Continental Reformers by having the Apocrypha set off from the rest of the OT. Coverdale (1535) called them "Apocrypha". All English Bibles prior to 1629 contained the Apocrypha. Matthew's Bible (1537), the Great Bible (1539), the Geneva Bible (1560), the Bishop's Bible (1568), and the King James Bible (1611) contained the Apocrypha. Soon after the publication of the KJV, however, the English Bibles began to drop the Apocrypha and eventually they disappeared entirely. The first English Bible to be printed in America (1782–83) lacked the Apocrypha. In 1826 the British and Foreign Bible Society decided to no longer print them. Today the trend is in the opposite direction, and English Bibles with the Apocrypha are becoming more popular again." <a href="#CITEREFEwert2010">Ewert 2010</a>, p. 104</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Wells1911-153"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Wells1911_153-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Wells1911_153-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Wells1911_153-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">"Fourteen books and parts of books are considered <i>Apocryphal</i> by Protestants. Three of these are recognized by Roman Catholics also as <i>Apocryphal</i>."<a href="#CITEREFWells1911">Wells 1911</a>, p. 41</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-155"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-155">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Canon_of_Trent#List" title="Canon of Trent">the Canon of Trent</a>:<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>But if anyone receive not, as sacred and canonical, the said books entire with all their parts, as they have been used to be read in the Catholic Church, and as they are contained in the old Latin vulgate edition; and knowingly and deliberately <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Contemn" title="Contemn">contemn</a> the traditions aforesaid; let him be <a href="/wiki/Anathema" title="Anathema">anathema</a>.</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><i>Decretum de Canonicis Scripturis</i>, Council of Trent, 8 April 1546</cite></div></blockquote></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-161"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-161">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"In all places where a reading from the deuterocanonical books (The Apocrypha) is listed, an alternate reading from the canonical Scriptures has also been provided."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[145]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-165"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-165">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The canon of the original Old Greek LXX is disputed. This table reflects the canon of the Old Testament as used currently in Orthodoxy.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-166"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-166">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">Βασιλειῶν</span></span> (Basileiōn) is the genitive plural of <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">Βασιλεῖα</span></span> (Basileia).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-167"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-167">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">That is, <i>Things set aside</i> from <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">Ἔσδρας Αʹ</span></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-168"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-168">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Also called Τωβείτ or Τωβίθ in some sources.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-170"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-170">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Not in Orthodox Canon, but originally included in the Septuagint.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[149]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-171"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-171">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Obdiou is genitive from "The vision <i>of</i> Obdias", which opens the book.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-172"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-172">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Originally placed after 3 Maccabees and before Psalms, but placed in an appendix of the Orthodox Canon.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-175"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-175">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The New Testament was written in Koine Greek, the Greek of daily conversation. The fact that from the first all the New Testament writings were written in Greek is conclusively demonstrated by their citations from the Old Testament ..." <a href="#CITEREFAlandAland1995">Aland &amp; Aland 1995</a>, p. 52</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-176"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-176">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"How came the twenty-seven books of the New Testament to be gathered together and made authoritative Christian scripture? 1. All the New Testament books were originally written in Greek. On the face of it this may surprise us." <a href="#CITEREFHunter1972">Hunter 1972</a>, p. 9</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-177"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-177">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"This is the language of the New Testament. By the time of Jesus the Romans had become the dominant military and political force, but the Greek language remained the 'common language' of the eastern Mediterranean and beyond, and Greek ..." <a href="#CITEREFDuffWenham2005">Duff &amp; Wenham 2005</a>, p. xxv</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-178"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-178">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"By far the most predominant element in the language of the New Testament is the Greek of common speech which was disseminated in the East by the Macedonian conquest, in the form which it had gradually assumed under the wider development ..." <a href="#CITEREFBlassThackeray2008">Blass &amp; Thackeray 2008</a>, p. <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=akD7DwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA2" rel="nofollow">2</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-179"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-179">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"In this short overview of the Greek language of the New Testament we will focus on those topics that are of greatest importance for the average reader, that is, those with important ..." <a href="#CITEREFAune2010">Aune 2010</a>, p. 61</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-195"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-195">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The Peshitta Old Testament was translated directly from the original Hebrew text, and the Peshitta New Testament directly from the original Greek" <a href="#CITEREFBrock1988">Brock 1988</a>, p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/stream/TheBibleInTheSyriacTradition/BrockTheBibleInTheSyriacTradition#page/n7/mode/2up" rel="nofollow">13</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Bromiley1995-196"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Bromiley1995_196-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Printed editions of the Peshitta frequently contain these books in order to fill the gaps. D. Harklean Version. The Harklean version is connected with the labors of Thomas of Harqel. When thousands were fleeing Khosrou's invading armies, ..." <a href="#CITEREFBromiley1995">Bromiley 1995</a>, p. 976</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-200"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-200">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Council of Trent confirmed the identical list/canon of sacred scriptures already anciently approved by the <a href="/wiki/Synod_of_Hippo" title="Synod of Hippo">Synod of Hippo</a> (Synod of 393), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Carthage_(397)" title="Council of Carthage (397)">Council of Carthage, 28 August 397</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Florence" title="Council of Florence">Council of Florence, 4 February 1442</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[169]</a></sup> – <a href="/wiki/Bull_of_Union_with_the_Copts" title="Bull of Union with the Copts">Bull of Union with the Copts</a> <i>seventh paragraph down</i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-WELS-276"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-WELS_276-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The United Methodists see Scripture as the primary source and criterion for Christian doctrine. They emphasize the importance of tradition, experience, and reason for Christian doctrine. Lutherans teach that the Bible is the sole source for Christian doctrine. The truths of Scripture do not need to be authenticated by tradition, human experience, or reason. Scripture is self authenticating and is true in and of itself."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wels.net_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-wels.net-275">[244]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Humphrey2013-277"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Humphrey2013_277-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"historically Anglicans have adopted what could be called a prima Scriptura position." <a href="#CITEREFHumphrey2013">Humphrey 2013</a>, p. 16</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-279"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-279">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"…they [from the Children of Israel] pervert words from their meanings, and have forgotten a part of what they were reminded …" <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> 5:18.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[245]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-Charles_Schmidt-230"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Charles_Schmidt_230-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSchmidt1889">Schmidt, Charles (1889). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_X-UROGF6ZcUC" rel="nofollow">"Chapter Five: The Poor and Unfortunate"</a>. <i>The Social Results of Early Christianity</i>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-Establishments-231"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Establishments_231-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/modelsforchristi0000unse" rel="nofollow"><i>Models for Christian Higher Education: Strategies for Survival and Success in the Twenty-First Century</i></a></span>. <a href="/wiki/William_B._Eerdmans_Publishing_Company" title="William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company">William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company</a>. 1997. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/modelsforchristi0000unse/page/290" rel="nofollow">290</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0802841216" title="Special:BookSources/978-0802841216"><bdi>978-0802841216</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 October</span> 2007</span>. <q>Wesleyan institutions, whether hospitals, orphanages, soup kitchens, or schools, historically were begun with the spirit to serve all people and to transform society.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Models+for+Christian+Higher+Education%3A+Strategies+for+Survival+and+Success+in+the+Twenty-First+Century&amp;rft.pages=290&amp;rft.pub=William+B.+Eerdmans+Publishing+Company&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0802841216&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fmodelsforchristi0000unse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABible"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Teasdale2014-232"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Teasdale2014_232-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTeasdale2014">Teasdale, Mark R. (2014). <i>Methodist Evangelism, American Salvation: The Home Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church, 1860–1920</i>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wipf_and_Stock_Publishers" title="Wipf and Stock Publishers">Wipf and Stock Publishers</a>. p. 203. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1620329160" title="Special:BookSources/978-1620329160"><bdi>978-1620329160</bdi></a>. <q>The new view of evangelism called for the denomination to undertake two new forms of activities: humanitarian aid and social witness. Humanitarian aid went beyond the individual help that many home missionaries were already providing to people within their care. It involved creating new structures that would augment the political, economic, and social systems so that those systems might be more humane. It included the establishment of Methodist hospitals in all the major cities in the United States. These hospitals were required to provide the best treatment possible free of charge to all who needed it, and were often staffed by deaconesses who trained as nurses. Homes for the aged and orphanages were also part of this work.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Methodist+Evangelism%2C+American+Salvation%3A+The+Home+Missions+of+the+Methodist+Episcopal+Church%2C+1860%E2%80%931920&amp;rft.pages=203&amp;rft.pub=Wipf+and+Stock+Publishers&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1620329160&amp;rft.aulast=Teasdale&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark+R.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABible"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-auto-233"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-auto_233-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Geoffrey Blainey; <i>A Short History of Christianity</i>; Penguin Viking; 2011</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Diane_Apostolos-Cappadona-244"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Diane_Apostolos-Cappadona_244-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFApostolos-Cappadona2016">Apostolos-Cappadona, Diane (July 2016). "Women in Religious Art". <i>Oxford Research Encyclopedia of Religion</i>. "What do we actually know about ancient Hebrew". <i>Australian Journal of Jewish Studies</i>. <b>27</b>: 11–31.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Journal+of+Jewish+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=What+do+we+actually+know+about+ancient+Hebrew&amp;rft.volume=27&amp;rft.pages=11-31&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.aulast=Young&amp;rft.aufirst=Ian&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABible"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFZuck1991"><a href="/wiki/Roy_B._Zuck" title="Roy B. Zuck">Zuck, Roy B.</a> (1991). <i>Basic Bible interpretation</i>. Wheaton, Ill.: Victor Books. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0896938199" title="Special:BookSources/978-0896938199"><bdi>978-0896938199</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Basic+Bible+interpretation&amp;rft.place=Wheaton%2C+Ill.&amp;rft.pub=Victor+Books&amp;rft.date=1991&amp;rft.isbn=978-0896938199&amp;rft.aulast=Zuck&amp;rft.aufirst=Roy+B.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABible"></span></li></ul>

House. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0310276814" title="Special:BookSources/978-0310276814"><bdi>978-0310276814</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+battle+for+the+Bible&amp;rft.place=Grand+Rapids&amp;rft.pub=Zondervan+Pub.+House&amp;rft.date=1976&amp;rft.isbn=978-0310276814&amp;rft.aulast=Lindsell&amp;rft.aufirst=Harold&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABible"></span></li>

<td class="" style="text-align:center; vertical-align:middle;; padding:0 1px;"><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="1300" data-file-width="1993" decoding="async" height="21" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Bible.malmesbury.arp.jpg/32px-Bible.malmesbury.arp.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Bible.malmesbury.arp.jpg/48px-Bible.malmesbury.arp.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Bible.malmesbury.arp.jpg/64px-Bible.malmesbury.arp.jpg 2x" width="32"/> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Bible" title="Portal:Bible">Bible portal</a></li><li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P_christianity.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/31px-P_christianity.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/47px-P_christianity.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/62px-P_christianity.svg.png 2x" width="31"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Christianity" title="Portal:Christianity">Christianity portal</a></li></ul></div></td>

<li><a href="/wiki/Summa_Theologica" title="Summa Theologica">Summa Theologica</a> (Roman Catholicism)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_modern" title="Early modern">Early modern</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Guru_Granth_Sahib" title="Guru Granth Sahib">Guru Granth Sahib</a> (Sikh)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Luther%27s_Large_Catechism" title="Luther's Large Catechism">Luther's Large Catechism</a> (Lutheranism)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Augsburg_Confession" title="Augsburg Confession">Augsburg Confession</a> (Protestantism)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Heidelberg_Catechism" title="Heidelberg Catechism">Heidelberg Catechism</a> (Protestantism)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer" title="Book of Common Prayer">Book of Common Prayer</a></i> (Anglicanism)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Roman_Missal" title="Roman Missal">Roman Missal</a> (Roman Catholicism)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Roman_Catechism" title="Roman Catechism">Roman Catechism</a> (Roman Catholicism)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Modernity" title="Modernity">Modern</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Mormon" title="Book of Mormon">Book of Mormon</a> (Mormonism, 1830)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ofudesaki" title="Ofudesaki">Ofudesaki</a> (Tenrikyo, 1869)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Kit%C3%A1b-i-Aqdas" title="Kitáb-i-Aqdas">Kitáb-i-Aqdas</a></i> (Baha'i, 1873)</li>
<li><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liber_AL_vel_Legis" title="Liber AL vel Legis">Liber AL vel Legis</a></i> (Thelemite, 1904)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Shadows" title="Book of Shadows">Book of Shadows</a> (Wiccan, 1950)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Dianetics:_The_Modern_Science_of_Mental_Health" title="Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health">Dianetics</a></i> (Scientologist, 1950)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Satanic_Bible" title="The Satanic Bible">The Satanic Bible</a></i> (Satanist, 1969)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Geniocracy" title="Geniocracy">Geniocracy</a> (Raelian, 1977)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism</a> (Roman Catholicism)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>
